EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure built in across the Southwest heading into the middle part of June, bringing excessive heat conditions to the region. High temperatures in Phoenix officially approached or exceeded 110 degrees between June 8-12th, which is well above the seasonal normal. The hottest temperature during this timeframe occurred on the 11th when the high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked at 114 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 36 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.

Hot and humid conditions during the early to mid afternoon on June 24, 2022 resulted in peak heat indices of 113 to 117 across Lake, Volusia, Orange, Seminole, Osceola, Okeechobee, and Brevard Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The AWOS at the Okeechobee County Airport, KOBE, measured a peak heat index of 115F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions during the early to mid afternoon on June 24, 2022 resulted in peak heat indices of 113 to 117 across Lake, Volusia, Orange, Seminole, Osceola, Okeechobee, and Brevard Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at the Sanford International Airport, KSFB, measured a peak heat index of 113F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions during the early to mid afternoon on June 24, 2022 resulted in peak heat indices of 113 to 117 across Lake, Volusia, Orange, Seminole, Osceola, Okeechobee, and Brevard Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The AWOS at Ormond Municipal Airport, KOMN, and New Smyrna Beach Municipal Airport, KEVB, both measured peak heat index values of 113F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures around 10 degrees above normal were experienced across the lower elevations of southeast Arizona on July 22. The hottest readings ranged from 107 to 112 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures around 10 degrees above normal occurred across the lower elevations of southeast Arizona on July 22, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached. The hottest temperature was 112 at Ajo. Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, Sells, Picacho, and Safford Airport (record) all topped out at 108 degrees.  Tucson International Airport reached 107.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure built in across the Southwest heading into the middle part of June, bringing excessive heat conditions to the region. High temperatures in Phoenix officially approached or exceeded 110 degrees between June 8-12th, which is well above the seasonal normal. The hottest temperature during this timeframe occurred on the 11th when the high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked at 114 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 36 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight direct fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure over the western CONUS resulted in excessive heat conditions across the Phoenix area for the end of August. Temperatures at Phoenix Sky Harbor topped out at 111 degrees on the 30th, while low temperatures near 90 degrees provided little overnight relief from the heat. Above normal temperatures continued into the start of September. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 9 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two direct fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure over the western CONUS resulted in excessive heat conditions across the Phoenix area for the end of August. Temperatures at Phoenix Sky Harbor topped out at 111 degrees on the 30th, while low temperatures near 90 degrees provided little overnight relief from the heat. Above normal temperatures continued into the start of September. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 9 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.

An anomalously strong ridge of high pressure over the Desert Southwest persisted into the latter part of July, leading to temperatures in excess of 110 degrees in Phoenix most days during this time. Temperatures during this time period peaked on the 22nd with Phoenix Sky Harbor recording a high of 114 degrees. Overnight temperatures provided little relief from the heat as morning lows remained in the 90s for several days. On the 22nd, the morning low temperature only cooled down to 95 degrees in Phoenix. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 81 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.

An expansive ridge of high pressure aloft forced a strong warm plume to the northeast, ahead of a frontal boundary on August 5.  The combination of temperatures in the mid to upper 90s and dew point readings in the mid 60s to around 70 led to heat index values from 105-110 for several hours across south central and southeast South Dakota.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in the upper 90s and dew point readings in the mid to upper 60s resulted in heat index values as high as 107 degrees near Ethan.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures were unusually hot on the 27th with high temperatures in the San Antonio area ranging from 100-103 degrees (the normal high is 93). Sixty-seven people were found in a tractor-trailer on the southwest side of San Antonio. Fifty-three people died of heat related illnesses. Forty-eight people died at the scene and five others died after being taken to hospitals. Forty of the victims were male and 13 were female. Their ages were not released.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures were unusually hot on the 27th with high temperatures in the San Antonio area ranging from 100-103 degrees (the normal high is 93). Sixty-seven people were found in a tractor-trailer on the southwest side of San Antonio. Fifty-three people died of heat related illnesses. Forty-eight people died at the scene and five others died after being taken to hospitals. Forty of the victims were male and 13 were female. Their ages were not released.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 5 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across parts of southeast Arizona July 17 and 18. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found outdoors in Tucson on the 17th and for an additional five individuals on the 18th. Of those, four were found in the desert: two on the Tohono O'odham Nation; one in east central Pima County; and one in Cochise County. A fifth individual died in the hospital shortly after being found in their Safford residence.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot high temperatures around 105 degrees, or 5 degrees above normal, occurred on July 17 and 18, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found outdoors in Tucson on the 17th and another found in the desert near Three Points on the 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 5 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across parts of southeast Arizona July 14. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individual found outdoors in Tucson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot high temperatures between 105 and 107, or 5 to 7 degrees above normal, occurred on July 14, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found outdoors in Tucson.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 5 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across parts of southeast Arizona July 8 and 9. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found outdoors in Tucson on the 9th and was a contributing factor in the death of another individual found outdoors in Tucson on the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot high temperatures between 105 and 107, or 5 to 7 degrees above normal, occurred on July 8 and 9, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found outdoors in Tucson on the 9th. Heat was found to be a contributing factor for another individual found outdoors in Tucson on the 8th. Epilepsy was a complicating factor in that fatality.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 5 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across parts of southeast Arizona July 17 and 18. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found outdoors in Tucson on the 17th and for an additional five individuals on the 18th. Of those, four were found in the desert: two on the Tohono O'odham Nation; one in east central Pima County; and one in Cochise County. A fifth individual died in the hospital shortly after being found in their Safford residence.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot high temperatures around 100 degrees, or 5 degrees above normal, occurred on July 18, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found in the desert 30 miles northeast of Douglas.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure over the western U.S. provided very warm and windy conditions. Areas near the coast reached into the 90s with records broken, along with wind gusts over 70 MPH in parts of the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures occurred across the region with widespread highs in the mid 80s to near 90 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure over the western U.S. provided very warm and windy conditions. Areas near the coast reached into the 90s with records broken, along with wind gusts over 70 MPH in parts of the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures occurred across the region with widespread highs in the mid 80s to lower 90s. Fullerton ASOS hit 91 degrees and Anaheim it 94 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure over the western U.S. provided very warm and windy conditions. Areas near the coast reached into the 90s with records broken, along with wind gusts over 70 MPH in parts of the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures occurred across the region with widespread highs in the mid 80s to near 90 degrees. John Wayne Airport ASOS hit 91 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure over the western U.S. provided very warm and windy conditions. Areas near the coast reached into the 90s with records broken, along with wind gusts over 70 MPH in parts of the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures occurred across the region with widespread highs in the mid 80s to lower 90s. The San Diego ASOS hit 91 degrees, breaking the record high temperature for the month of February.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure over the western U.S. provided very warm and windy conditions. Areas near the coast reached into the 90s with records broken, along with wind gusts over 70 MPH in parts of the mountains.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Warm temperatures occurred across the region with widespread highs in the mid 80s to near 90 degrees. Ramona ASOS reported a high of 85 degrees and El Cajon reached 89 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge centered over the mid and lower Mississippi Valley on June 17th and 18th resulted in abnormally hot temperatures across much of the Four State Region, with afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees each day. Wet grounds from widespread rains back on the 10th-11th over Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and much of North Louisiana also did not allow for much mixing of dewpoints, with oppressively hot conditions observed as heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees each day.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built back in over much of the Four State Region before expanding back west into Central Texas on June 22nd-26th, with the strong subsidence beneath the ridge resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower 100s across North Louisiana. Limited mixing of dewpoints was observed each day, resulting in oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE OF FRESNO AND KINGS COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper ridge built into California on May 24 and 25 resulting in a period of summer like temperatures for three days between May 24 and May 26.  May 25 with the warmest day of the three with with most locations in the San Joaquin Valley and lower Sierra foothills having maximum temperatures between 100 and 104 degrees prompting the issuance of the first Heat Advisory of the season.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 104 degrees on May 25.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High dew point temperatures combined with very hot daytime high temperatures on May 9th, resulting in heat index values in excess of 111 degrees for Starr and Zapata County during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Zapata Airport AWOS site first recorded heat index values reaching or exceeding 111 degrees around 1:55 PM CDT. Heat index values then remained above 111 degrees through 6:45 PM, topping out around 114 degrees at 3:35PM CDT. No heat-related injuries or fatalities were reported as of this writing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very warm temperatures and high humidity provided dangerous heat conditions over the Coastal Bend during the afternoons of the 10th, 11th, and 12th. Afternoon heat index values increase to around 112 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values rose above 110 degrees during the afternoon. Maximum heat index values were around 112 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures from the mid 80s to mid 90s were experienced in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona on March 26. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two males found in the desert, one southeast of Green Valley in Pima County and another west of Douglas in Cochise County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 10 to 15 degrees above normal, near 90 degrees, were experienced in southeast Pima County on March 26 causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be approached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one male found in the desert seven miles southeast of Green Valley.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure with a 594 dm 500 mb high centered near the Four Corners led to slightly above normal temperatures during the beginning of August. Highs at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked at 107 degrees on the 2nd, while lows were in the mid to upper 80s each morning. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 12 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two indirect fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 12 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three fatalities (2 direct and 1 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge centered over the mid and lower Mississippi Valley on June 17th and 18th resulted in abnormally hot temperatures across much of the Four State Region, with afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees each day. Wet grounds from widespread rains back on the 10th-11th over Southeast Oklahoma, Southwest Arkansas, and much of North Louisiana also did not allow for much mixing of dewpoints, with oppressively hot conditions observed as heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees each day.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built back in over much of the Four State Region before expanding back west into Central Texas on June 22nd-26th, with the strong subsidence beneath the ridge resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the mid 90s to near 100 degrees across Southeast Oklahoma. Limited mixing of dewpoints was observed each day, resulting in oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High dew point temperatures combined with very hot daytime high temperatures on May 9th, resulting in heat index values in excess of 111 degrees for Starr and Zapata County during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This event is based largely on observed heat index values across Zapata County, the which saw heat indices top out at 114 degrees. Given the higher heat index values in Zapata counties, it is inferred that Starr County also experienced heat index values in excess of 111 degrees for at least two hours. The Falcon Lake RAWS site recorded values technically reaching Excessive Heat criteria, but this observation site has a history of running notably higher than surrounding areas. No heat-related injuries or fatalities were reported as of this writing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures around 10 degrees above normal were experienced across the lower elevations of southeast Arizona on July 22. The hottest readings ranged from 107 to 112 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures around 10 degrees above normal occurred across the lower elevations of southeast Arizona on July 22, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached. The hottest temperature was 112 at Ajo. Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, Sells, Picacho, and Safford Airport (record) all topped out at 108 degrees.  Tucson International Airport reached 107.

CZ_NAME: UPPER GILA RIVER AND ARAVAIPA VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 5 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across parts of southeast Arizona July 17 and 18. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found outdoors in Tucson on the 17th and for an additional five individuals on the 18th. Of those, four were found in the desert: two on the Tohono O'odham Nation; one in east central Pima County; and one in Cochise County. A fifth individual died in the hospital shortly after being found in their Safford residence.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot high temperatures around 105 degrees, or 5 to 7 degrees above normal, occurred on July 18, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual who dies in the hospital shortly after being found in their Safford home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot high temperatures between 101 and 103, or 2 to 4 degrees above normal, occurred on August 16, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two elderly individuals found in their Tucson homes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures around 5 degrees above normal were experienced in southeast Cochise County on June 15. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found in the desert.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures just above 100 degrees caused the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached on June 15. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found in the desert near Douglas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early September heat starting in August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The SDAPL observation site in Apple Valley observed daily highs ranging from the upper 90s to upwards of 109 degrees through much of early September. The highest daily maximum temperature of 109 degrees occurred on the afternoons of Thursday, September 1st, Friday September 2nd, and Tuesday September 6th, with a high of 105 degrees occurring on both the 3rd of September. Highs on Friday, September 9th were significantly cooler due to clouds and rain associated with the approach of Hurricane Kay, which ended the heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early September heat starting in August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The SDOCL observation site in Ocotillo Wells observed daily highs ranging from 103 degrees to upwards of 116 degrees through much of early September. The highest daily maximum temperature of 116 degrees occurred on the afternoon of Tuesday September 6th, with a high of 115 degrees occurring on both the 5th of September. Highs on Friday, September 9th were significantly cooler due to clouds and rain associated with the approach of Hurricane Kay, which ended the heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge moved into the Southwestern United States on May 13th, causing temperatures to soar above seasonal normals through the 15th before gradually falling back towards seasonal average.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures soared well above seasonal normals starting May 13th and lasting through the 15th. Yorba Linda reached a high of 94 degrees on the 13th while John Wayne International Airport reached 86 degrees. The hottest temperatures occurred on the 14th, when Yorba Linda recorded a high of 95 degrees, while John Wayne International recorded a high of 87 degrees. Temperatures were a bit lower on the 15th, when Yorba Linda topped out at 86 degrees and John Wayne International reached 77 degrees.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge moved into the Southwestern United States on May 13th, causing temperatures to soar above seasonal normals through the 15th before gradually falling back towards seasonal average.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures soared well above seasonal normals starting May 13th and lasting through the 15th. Many locations in the Inland Empire reached the middle to upper 90s on the 13th, when Chino Airport hit 97 degrees, Riverside Airport (RAL) reached 95 degrees, and San Bernardino International Airport reached 95 degrees. Several locations reached the upper 90s to just over 100 degrees on the 14th. Chino reached 101 degrees, Riverside Airport reached 98 degrees, and San Bernardino International Airport reached 99 degrees. Slightly cooler temperatures were observed on the 15th, with all three of the aforementioned locations reaching 91 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge moved into the Southwestern United States on May 13th, causing temperatures to soar above seasonal normals through the 15th before gradually falling back towards seasonal average.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures soared well above seasonal normals starting May 13th and lasting through the 15th. High temperatures topped out in the middle 80s to lower 90s on the 13th, when the Ramona Airport reached 92 degrees and Gillespie Field reached 90 degrees. Temperatures reached the upper 80s to middle 90s across many inland valley areas on the 14th. The Ramona Airport reached 96 degrees, while Gillespie Field reached 93 degrees. Slightly cooler temperatures were observed on the 15th, with Ramona reaching 91 degrees and Gillespie Field reaching 84 degrees.

Slightly cooler temperatures were observed on the 15th, with Hesperia reaching 86 degrees and Apple Valley reaching 90 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures of around 90 to the lower 90s...with dewpoints in the upper 60s to around 70...occurred across portions of interior Downeast Maine during the 4th. The combination of temperatures and dewpoints produced apparent temperatures in the mid to upper 90s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures of around 90 to the lower 90s...with dewpoints from the upper 60s to around 70...combined to produce apparent temperatures in the mid to upper 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures ranged from around 90 to the lower 90s across portions of east-central Maine...to the lower 90s Downeast. Dewpoint temperatures ranged from around 70 to the lower 70s across the region. The combination of temperatures and dewpoints produced apparent temperatures in the mid to upper 90s across east-central areas...with readings in the upper 90s to around 105 Downeast.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures of around 90 to the lower 90s....with dewpoints of around 70 to the lower 70s...combined to produce apparent temperatures ranging from the mid 90s to around 100.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over interior northern California brought widespread moderate to locally high heat risk to the region the last week of May. Triple digit temperatures were observed across much of the Valley on Tuesday May 24 and Wednesday May 25 with the hottest temperatures on May 25th. Several new record daily high temperatures were set or tied in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high temperature Tuesday the 24th at Sacramento Executive Airport reached |100 degrees which tied the previous record. A record high temperature of 102 was set at Sacramento Executive Airport on Wednesday the 25th. A new record high temperature of 103 was also set in downtown Sacramento on Wednesday the 25th. Two cooling centers were open through 8:00 pm in Sacramento County. ASOS reported high temperature readings ranged from 97 to 102 degrees during the event.

Several new record daily high temperatures were set or tied in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reported high temperature readings ranged from 97 to 102 degrees during the event.

Highs on Friday, September 9th were significantly cooler due to clouds and rain associated with the approach of Hurricane Kay, which ended the heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early September heat starting in August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Palm Springs International Airport observed daily highs ranging from 106 degrees to upwards of 114 degrees through much of early September. The highest daily maximum temperature of 114 degrees occurred on the afternoon of Tuesday September 6th, with a high of 113 degrees occurring on both the 5th of September. Highs on Friday, September 9th were significantly cooler due to clouds and rain associated with the approach of Hurricane Kay, which ended the heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 3 to 5 degrees above normal were experienced in Pima County on September 2. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual in Green Valley.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot high temperatures 101 to 103 degrees, or 3 to 5 degrees above normal, occurred on September 2 causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found in their Green Valley home.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over interior northern California brought widespread moderate to locally high heat risk to the region the last week of May. Triple digit temperatures were observed across much of the Valley on Tuesday May 24 and Wednesday May 25 with the hottest temperatures on May 25th. Several new record daily high temperatures were set or tied in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Zone 18 were in the heat advisory area and reported high temperature readings that ranged from 99 to 104 degrees during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over interior northern California brought widespread moderate to locally high heat risk to the region the last week of May. Triple digit temperatures were observed across much of the Valley on Tuesday May 24 and Wednesday May 25 with the hottest temperatures on May 25th. Several new record daily high temperatures were set or tied in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 103 was set at the Redding Airport on Wednesday the 25th. A new record warm low temperature of 73 was also set at the Redding Airport on Wednesday the 25th. A new record warm low temperature of 71 was also set at the Red Bluff Airport on Wednesday the 25th. ASOS reported high temperature readings ranged from 99 to 104 degrees during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over interior northern California brought widespread moderate to locally high heat risk to the region the last week of May. Triple digit temperatures were observed across much of the Valley on Tuesday May 24 and Wednesday May 25 with the hottest temperatures on May 25th. Several new record daily high temperatures were set or tied in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 103 was set at the Stockton Airport on Wednesday the 25th. A new record high temperature of 100 was also set at the Modesto Airport on Wednesday the 25th. ASOS reported high temperature readings ranged from 99 to 102 degrees during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 5 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced across parts of southeast Arizona July 17 and 18. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found outdoors in Tucson on the 17th and for an additional five individuals on the 18th. Of those, four were found in the desert: two on the Tohono O'odham Nation; one in east central Pima County; and one in Cochise County. A fifth individual died in the hospital shortly after being found in their Safford residence.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot high temperatures 100 to 105 degrees, or 5 degrees above normal, occurred on July 18, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert, one near Sells and another near Queen's Well.

The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found in the desert fifteen miles southwest of Topawa.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat indices peaked around 105 degrees during the afternoon along and south of U.S. Highway 60. Some specific peak heat index values included 105 degrees at Poplar Bluff, 109 at Sikeston, and 103 at Cape Girardeau. The heat and humidity occurred just ahead of a weak cold front as it crossed the lower Ohio Valley and southeast Missouri.

A large upper ridge prevailed across the region from mid-June through the end of the month resulting in very hot and humid conditions across the Mid-South. The heat was most intense on June 12th and 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values climbed to 110 degrees or greater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge nearly stationary over the territory for most of March produced a gentle breeze and limited shower development for the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure built back in over much of the Four State Region before expanding back west into Central Texas on June 22nd-26th, with the strong subsidence beneath the ridge resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower 100s across extreme Northeast Texas. Limited mixing of dewpoints was observed each day, resulting in oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure developed across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, producing a record-breaking early season heat wave. Numerous record highs and warm lows were established, including the first triple-digit temperatures experienced since 2016 in Cape Girardeau and since 2013 in Poplar Bluff. Cape Girardeau broke three daily high temperature records. Low temperatures in the lower 80's were observed in several locations, setting monthly and all-time records in some cases. Cape Girardeau tied its all-time warmest low of 81 degrees. Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees starting on June 12 and continued through June 16. The most oppressive day was June 13, when dewpoints in the mid 70's to around 80 produced heat index values of 110 to 115.

A ridge of high pressure dominated the Four Corners region. This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across much of western Colorado. Conditions were exceptionally dry which translated to minimum humidities in the single digits to low teens in the lower valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 100 to 105 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations. The Grand Junction Regional Airport set a new record high temperature for the day of 102 degrees. A 52-year old man who was mountain biking the end of the Palisade Plunge trail outside of Palisade ran out of water while biking and died as a result of heat-related illness.

High pressure over the Eastern Pacific combined with low pressure over the southwestern United States to produce Santa Ana winds over the mountains of Southern California, with several gusts of 50 to 70 mph. This also allowed temperatures across areas east of the mountains to climb well above seasonal averages, reaching the upper 80s to middle 90s across many coastal areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures topped out in the upper 80s to lower 90s across much of the San Diego County Valleys.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the Eastern Pacific combined with low pressure over the southwestern United States to produce Santa Ana winds over the mountains of Southern California, with several gusts of 50 to 70 mph. This also allowed temperatures across areas east of the mountains to climb well above seasonal averages, reaching the upper 80s to middle 90s across many coastal areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures topped out in the upper 80s and lower 90s across much of Inland Orange County. The Fullerton ASOS recorded a high of 88 degrees, and an observation near Yorba Linda recorded a high of 90 degrees both on March 23rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge nearly stationary over the territory for most of March produced a gentle breeze and limited shower development for the area.

Cape Girardeau tied its all-time warmest low of 81 degrees. Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees starting on June 12 and continued through June 16. The most oppressive day was June 13, when dewpoints in the mid 70's to around 80 produced heat index values of 110 to 115.

A strong upper level ridge of high pressure developed across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, producing a record-breaking early season heat wave. Numerous record highs and warm lows were established, including the first triple-digit temperatures experienced since 2016 in Cape Girardeau and since 2013 in Poplar Bluff. Cape Girardeau broke three daily high temperature records. Low temperatures in the lower 80's were observed in several locations, setting monthly and all-time records in some cases. Cape Girardeau tied its all-time warmest low of 81 degrees. Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees starting on June 12 and continued through June 16. The most oppressive day was June 13, when dewpoints in the mid 70's to around 80 produced heat index values of 110 to 115.

High pressure over the Eastern Pacific combined with low pressure over the southwestern United States to produce Santa Ana winds over the mountains of Southern California, with several gusts of 50 to 70 mph. This also allowed temperatures across areas east of the mountains to climb well above seasonal averages, reaching the upper 80s to middle 90s across many coastal areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures topped out in the middle to upper 80s across much of the San Diego County Coast.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the Eastern Pacific combined with low pressure over the southwestern United States to produce Santa Ana winds over the mountains of Southern California, with several gusts of 50 to 70 mph. This also allowed temperatures across areas east of the mountains to climb well above seasonal averages, reaching the upper 80s to middle 90s across many coastal areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures topped out in the upper 80s to lower 90s across much of the Orange County Coast. John Wayne International recorded a high of 85 degrees on March 23rd.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over the Eastern Pacific combined with low pressure over the southwestern United States to produce Santa Ana winds over the mountains of Southern California, with several gusts of 50 to 70 mph. This also allowed temperatures across areas east of the mountains to climb well above seasonal averages, reaching the upper 80s to middle 90s across many coastal areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures ranged from the middle 80s to the middle 90s across much of the Inland Empire on March 23rd. The Chino ASOS recorded a high of 91 degrees.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built back in over much of the Four State Region before expanding back west into Central Texas on June 22nd-26th, with the strong subsidence beneath the ridge resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower 100s across Southwest Arkansas. Limited mixing of dewpoints was observed each day, resulting in oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In wake of a complex of showers and thunderstorms that moved through North Louisiana on June 10th, an upper level ridge of high pressure built into the region on the 11th, and lingered over the area through the 13th. Increasing subsidence beneath the ridge yielded afternoon temperatures in the mid to upper 90s across North Louisiana, with very humid conditions prevalent, added by the increased evapotranspiration from the recent rains. Thus, oppressive heat was observed, with heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees each day.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built back in over much of the Four State Region before expanding back west into Central Texas on June 22nd-26th, with the strong subsidence beneath the ridge resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower 100s across East Texas. Mixing was sufficient enough for heat indices to remain generally below 105 degrees on the 22nd across much of East Texas, but limited mixing of dewpoints occurred on the 23rd and 24th, resulting in more oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees. Better mixing was observed on the 25th and 26th, such that heat indices were generally below 105 degrees.

Another round of hazardous heat and humidity occurred. Afternoon heat indices peaked around 105 degrees. Specific readings included 105 at Poplar Bluff, 107 at Cape Girardeau, and 109 at Perryville. The heat occurred under a strong southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front over the central Plains.

Hazardous levels of heat and humidity occurred across the Pennyrile region of western Kentucky, from the Henderson and Owensboro areas south across Madisonville to Elkton. Afternoon heat indices peaked around 105 degrees. Specific readings included 106 at Henderson, 105 at Madisonville, and 109 at Elkton. The heat occurred under a strong southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front over the central Plains.

An upper ridge was anchored over the Southern Plains on August 3rd, resulting in very hot and humid conditions in place across all of the Four State Region. As a result, afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s and lower 100s across North Louisiana, with resultant heat indices generally ranging from 105 to 108 degrees, despite an upper level disturbance over Central Louisiana and Mississippi focusing scattered afternoon showers and thunderstorms across portions of North Louisiana. Slightly cooler conditions were observed on the 4th, which correlated to slightly lower heat indices below 105 degrees across North Louisiana.

Upper ridging was anchored from the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles southeast into the Lower Mississippi Valley on August 17th, maintaining hot and humid conditions across much of the Four State Region. Meanwhile, a weak surface front drifted south across Lower East Texas along/south of Interstate 20, with compressional warming along and south of the front contributing to afternoon temperatures climbing into the lower 100s. Combined with the humid conditions in place, heat indices ranged from 105-108 degrees.  Cooler conditions were observed the next day on the 8th in wake of the weak surface frontal passage, with triggered an increase in scattered showers and thunderstorms.

A potent upper level ridge of high pressure moved over the region and persisted through the end of July and the first of August. Across the region, multiple areas in the lower elevations reached critical thresholds for heat risk, while many mountain zones saw consecutive days with high temperatures exceeding 95 degrees Fahrenheit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk values at the Moro GHCN site recorded several days between July 25th through Aug. 1st of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered over the Desert Southwest expanded over the Pacific Northwest bringing a brief hot spell to the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure expanded into the region bringing a very warm air mass. High temperatures peaked near 100 degrees on the 7th in portions of Southwest Washington and through the Columbia River Gorge. This was a brief event however as high temperatures were in the 80s in the days immediately following.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge centered over the mid and lower Mississippi Valley on June 18th resulted in abnormally hot temperatures across much of the Four State Region, with afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across East Texas. Wet grounds were observed across much of East Texas from scattered showers and thunderstorms that developed during the afternoon and evening of the 17th, which did not mix out completely on the 18th resulting in oppressively hot conditions. Heat indices on the 18th ranged from 105-109 degrees across East Texas, before better mixing on the 19th resulted in lower heat indices below 105 degrees despite temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees.

Wet grounds were observed across much of East Texas from scattered showers and thunderstorms that developed during the afternoon and evening of the 17th, which did not mix out completely on the 18th resulting in oppressively hot conditions. Heat indices on the 18th ranged from 105-109 degrees across East Texas, before better mixing on the 19th resulted in lower heat indices below 105 degrees despite temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees.

Heat indices on the 18th ranged from 105-109 degrees across East Texas, before better mixing on the 19th resulted in lower heat indices below 105 degrees despite temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built back in over much of the Four State Region before expanding back west into Central Texas on June 22nd-26th, with the strong subsidence beneath the ridge resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower 100s across East Texas. Mixing was sufficient enough for heat indices to remain generally below 105 degrees on the 22nd across much of East Texas, but limited mixing of dewpoints occurred on the 23rd and 24th, resulting in more oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees. Better mixing was observed on the 25th and 26th, such that heat indices were generally below 105 degrees.

Hazardous levels of heat and humidity occurred across the Pennyrile region of western Kentucky, from the Henderson and Owensboro areas south across Madisonville to Elkton. Afternoon heat indices peaked around 105 degrees. Specific readings included 106 at Henderson, 105 at Madisonville, and 109 at Elkton. The heat occurred under a strong southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front over the central Plains.

An upper ridge was anchored over the Southern Plains on August 3rd, resulting in very hot and humid conditions in place across all of the Four State Region. As a result, afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s and lower 100s across North Louisiana, with resultant heat indices generally ranging from 105 to 108 degrees, despite an upper level disturbance over Central Louisiana and Mississippi focusing scattered afternoon showers and thunderstorms across portions of North Louisiana. Slightly cooler conditions were observed on the 4th, which correlated to slightly lower heat indices below 105 degrees across North Louisiana.

Upper ridging was anchored from the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles southeast into the Lower Mississippi Valley on August 17th, maintaining hot and humid conditions across much of the Four State Region. Meanwhile, a weak surface front drifted south across Lower East Texas along/south of Interstate 20, with compressional warming along and south of the front contributing to afternoon temperatures climbing into the lower 100s. Combined with the humid conditions in place, heat indices ranged from 105-108 degrees.  Cooler conditions were observed the next day on the 8th in wake of the weak surface frontal passage, with triggered an increase in scattered showers and thunderstorms.

CZ_NAME: EAST SLOPES OF THE OREGON CASCADES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure from the four corners region extended northward into the Pacific Northwest, which resulted in well above normal temperatures across the region for several days. Many stations saw temperatures exceed critical heat risk thresholds, while stations in some mountain zones saw high temperatures consecutively meet or exceed 95 degrees under the strengthening high pressure aloft.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Colgate RAWS recorded consecutive maximum daily temperatures of 95 degrees or greater on Aug. 8th and 9th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure from the four corners region extended northward into the Pacific Northwest, which resulted in well above normal temperatures across the region for several days. Many stations saw temperatures exceed critical heat risk thresholds, while stations in some mountain zones saw high temperatures consecutively meet or exceed 95 degrees under the strengthening high pressure aloft.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk values at the Dallesport Airport GHCN site recorded temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria on the 8th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A record-breaking and prolonged heat wave started at the end of August and persisted through the week of Labor Day. Numerous records were broken and multiple wildfires were started as the result of extreme temperatures and drought.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Idyllwild reached a high temperature of 96 degrees on August 31, breaking the previous record of 94 set in 2017.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A record-breaking and prolonged heat wave started at the end of August and persisted through the week of Labor Day. Numerous records were broken and multiple wildfires were started as the result of extreme temperatures and drought.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Anaheim broke their daily high temperature record, reaching 106 degrees, breaking the previous record of 102 set in 2007. This also breaks the all-time monthly high temperature for the month of August, breaking the previous record of 105 degrees set on August 18, 2020.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A record-breaking and prolonged heat wave started at the end of August and persisted through the week of Labor Day. Numerous records were broken and multiple wildfires were started as the result of extreme temperatures and drought.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Campo tied the daily high temperature record, reaching 105 degrees, tying the previous record of 105 degrees set in 1998.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A record-breaking and prolonged heat wave started at the end of August and persisted through the week of Labor Day. Numerous records were broken and multiple wildfires were started as the result of extreme temperatures and drought.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous pre-hospital related calls and transports were recorded through the duration of the heatwave. Six calls were received on August 30, with age range of 7-79 years, with most seeing mild symptoms; many were outside recreating or working. On August 31, 13 calls were placed with the age range of 18-86 years, with 11 experiencing mild symptoms, 1 seeing moderate symptoms and 1 acute.

The combination of high temperatures in the upper 90s and dew points in the mid to upper 70s led to heat indices in the 105 to 110 degree range across the western half of Middle Tennessee from June 13 through June 16. This heat wave caused roughly 15 heat-related injuries in Nashville over the 4 day period, per the Nashville Office of Emergency Management. No deaths were reported.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built into the region on the 12th, and lingered over the area through the 13th, following widespread rainfall that fell over the region on the 10th. Increasing subsidence beneath the ridge yielded afternoon temperatures in the mid 90s across Southwest Arkansas, with very humid conditions prevalent, added by the increased evapotranspiration from the recent rains. Thus, oppressive heat was observed, with heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees each day.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built into Northeast Louisiana on the 12th, and lingered over the area through the 13th, following widespread rainfall that fell over the region on the 10th. An upper level ridge centered over the mid and lower Mississippi Valley on June 18th resulted in abnormally hot temperatures across much of the Four State Region, with afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across East Texas. Wet grounds were observed across much of East Texas from scattered showers and thunderstorms that developed during the afternoon and evening of the 17th, which did not mix out completely on the 18th resulting in oppressively hot conditions. Heat indices on the 18th ranged from 105-109 degrees across East Texas, before better mixing on the 19th resulted in lower heat indices below 105 degrees despite temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees.

A large upper ridge prevailed across the region from mid-June through the end of the month resulting in very hot and humid conditions across the Mid-South. The heat was most intense on June 12th and 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values of 110 degrees or greater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure built back in over much of the Four State Region before expanding back west into Central Texas on June 22nd-26th, with the strong subsidence beneath the ridge resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower 100s across East Texas. Mixing was sufficient enough for heat indices to remain generally below 105 degrees on the 22nd across much of East Texas, but limited mixing of dewpoints occurred on the 23rd and 24th, resulting in more oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees. Better mixing was observed on the 25th and 26th, such that heat indices were generally below 105 degrees.

CZ_NAME: FOOTHILLS OF THE NORTHERN BLUE MOUNTAINS OF OREGON
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper level ridging and persistent surface high pressure in the Columbia Basin resulted in several areas reaching or exceeding critical heat risk thresholds during this period, with some mountain sites also seeing consecutive days of 95 degrees or greater temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk values at the Pendleton Airport and Pilot Rock GHCN sites recorded temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria on Aug. 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper level ridging and persistent surface high pressure in the Columbia Basin resulted in several areas reaching or exceeding critical heat risk thresholds during this period, with some mountain sites also seeing consecutive days of 95 degrees or greater temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk values at the La Grande GHCN site recorded consecutive days between Aug. 18th and 19th of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Prolonged southwest flow and upper ridging lead to a period of temperatures in the mid to upper 90s with dewpoints in the low to mid 70s. Resulting heat index values rose to the mid to upper 100s across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105F on August 9th.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE MOUNTAINS NORTH OF HIGHWAY 198
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure that was centered over the Great Basin area built westward into California on August 31st and brought a period of hot and dry weather to the area which prevailed across the area through much of early September.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 108 degrees.

A period of hot weather brought very warm temperatures to the interior of Western Washington, helping to set a few record maximum temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at the Olympia airport recorded a record max temperature of 96 degrees. This beats the previous record of 94 set in 1981.

CZ_NAME: CASCADES OF WHATCOM AND SKAGIT COUNTIES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of hot weather brought very warm temperatures to the interior of Western Washington, helping to set a few record maximum temperatures.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observation site at Diablo Dam in the North Cascades set a record high temperature of 103 degrees on August 18. An excessive heat warning was in effect during this time. Hot conditions persisted into the 19th, with a high temperature of 93 degrees but this did not break a record.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat and high humidity along a warm front settled over far southern WI. Heat index values rose into the lower 100's.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values ranging from 100 to 103 degrees.

Mixing was sufficient enough for heat indices to remain generally below 105 degrees on the 22nd across much of East Texas, but limited mixing of dewpoints occurred on the 23rd and 24th, resulting in more oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees. Better mixing was observed on the 25th and 26th, such that heat indices were generally below 105 degrees.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values ranging from 98 to 103 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This heat event was more pronounced than the previous one in June. Dew points pooled ahead of a frontal boundary Tuesday afternoon, August 2nd. These dew points that rose into the 70s combined with actual temperatures in the mid to upper 90s to support heat indices in the 100 to 115 degree range for several hours during the afternoon and evening of Tuesday, August 2nd. At one point Tuesday afternoon, heat indices rose to 115 degrees at Hutchinson, 114 degrees at Granite Falls, and 112 degrees at both Redwood Falls and New Ulm. Just west of the Twin Cities, heat indices were highest near Buffalo which rose to 111 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several temperature gauges measured heat indices between 105 and 114 degrees during the afternoon and evening hours.

In wake of a complex of showers and thunderstorms that moved through Southeast Oklahoma on June 10th, an upper level ridge of high pressure built into the region on the 11th, and lingered over the area through the 13th. Increasing subsidence beneath the ridge yielded afternoon temperatures in the mid to upper 90s across Southeast Oklahoma, with very humid conditions prevalent, added by the increased evapotranspiration from the recent rains. Thus, oppressive heat was observed, with heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees each day.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built into the region on the 12th, and lingered over the area through the 13th, following widespread rainfall that fell over the region on the 10th. Increasing subsidence beneath the ridge yielded afternoon temperatures in the mid 90s across Southwest Arkansas, with very humid conditions prevalent, added by the increased evapotranspiration from the recent rains. Thus, oppressive heat was observed, with heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees each day.

An upper level ridge centered over the mid and lower Mississippi Valley on June 18th resulted in abnormally hot temperatures across much of the Four State Region, with afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across East Texas. Wet grounds were observed across much of East Texas from scattered showers and thunderstorms that developed during the afternoon and evening of the 17th, which did not mix out completely on the 18th resulting in oppressively hot conditions. Heat indices on the 18th ranged from 105-109 degrees across East Texas, before better mixing on the 19th resulted in lower heat indices below 105 degrees despite temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures continued into the first week of August, with air temperature and/or heat index values exceeding 105 degrees. No heat related injuries were reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: No heat related injuries were reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hazardous levels of heat and humidity occurred, mainly along and west of Interstate 57.   Afternoon heat indices peaked between 105 and 109 degrees. The peak heat index ranged from 105 degrees at Carbondale to 109 degrees at the Williamson County airport. The heat occurred under a brisk southwest wind flow between high pressure over the central Gulf coast and low pressure over the upper Great Lakes.

An upper level ridge of high pressure built into Northeast Louisiana on the 12th, and lingered over the area through the 13th, following widespread rainfall that fell over the region on the 10th. Increasing subsidence beneath the ridge yielded afternoon temperatures in the mid 90s across Northeast Louisiana, with very humid conditions prevalent, added by the increased evapotranspiration from the recent rains. Thus, oppressive heat was observed, with heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees each day.

An upper level ridge centered over the mid and lower Mississippi Valley on June 18th resulted in abnormally hot temperatures across much of the Four State Region, with afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees across East Texas. Wet grounds were observed across much of East Texas from scattered showers and thunderstorms that developed during the afternoon and evening of the 17th, which did not mix out completely on the 18th resulting in oppressively hot conditions. Heat indices on the 18th ranged from 105-109 degrees across East Texas, before better mixing on the 19th resulted in lower heat indices below 105 degrees despite temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees.

A large upper ridge prevailed across the region from mid-June through the end of the month resulting in very hot and humid conditions across the Mid-South. The heat was most intense on June 12th and 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values climbed to 110 degrees or greater.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge of high pressure built back in over much of the Four State Region before expanding back west into Central Texas on June 22nd-26th, with the strong subsidence beneath the ridge resulting in afternoon temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower 100s across East Texas. Mixing was sufficient enough for heat indices to remain generally below 105 degrees on the 22nd across much of East Texas, but limited mixing of dewpoints occurred on the 23rd and 24th, resulting in more oppressively hot conditions as heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees. Better mixing was observed on the 25th and 26th, such that heat indices were generally below 105 degrees.

In wake of a complex of showers and thunderstorms that moved through North Louisiana on June 10th, an upper level ridge of high pressure built into the region on the 11th, and lingered over the area through the 13th. Increasing subsidence beneath the ridge yielded afternoon temperatures in the mid to upper 90s across North Louisiana, with very humid conditions prevalent, added by the increased evapotranspiration from the recent rains. Thus, oppressive heat was observed, with heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees each day.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE MOUNTAINS NORTH OF HIGHWAY 198
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure which prevailed over the area between August 16 and August 20 provided for much warmer than normal temperatures across the area with dangerous heat prevailing during the daytime across the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills, lower Sierra foothills and the Kern River Valley.  An upper trough pushed into the Pacific Northwest on August 21 which weakened the large high pressure center and brought a cooling trend to the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 102 and 106 degrees each day between August 16 and August 20.

An upper trough pushed into the Pacific Northwest on August 21 which weakened the large high pressure center and brought a cooling trend to the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 104 and 108 degrees each day between August 16 and August 20.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: In wake of a complex of showers and thunderstorms that moved through North Louisiana on June 10th, an upper level ridge of high pressure built into the region on the 11th, and lingered over the area through the 13th. Increasing subsidence beneath the ridge yielded afternoon temperatures in the mid to upper 90s across North Louisiana, with very humid conditions prevalent, added by the increased evapotranspiration from the recent rains. Thus, oppressive heat was observed, with heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees each day.

In wake of a complex of showers and thunderstorms that moved through Southwest Arkansas on June 10th, an upper level ridge of high pressure built into the region on the 11th, and lingered over the area through the 13th. An upper ridge was anchored over the Southern Plains on August 3rd, resulting in very hot and humid conditions in place across all of the Four State Region. As a result, afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s and lower 100s across McCurtain County Oklahoma, with resultant heat indices generally ranging from 105 to 107 degrees. Slightly cooler conditions was observed on the 4th, which correlated to slightly lower heat indices below 105 degrees.

Temperatures of around 90 to the lower 90s...with dewpoints in the upper 60s to around 70...occurred across portions of interior Downeast Maine during the 4th. The combination of temperatures and dewpoints produced apparent temperatures in the mid to upper 90s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures of around 90 to the lower 90s...with dewpoints from the upper 60s to around 70...combined to produce apparent temperatures in the mid to upper 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hazardous levels of heat and humidity occurred, mainly along and west of Interstate 57.   Afternoon heat indices peaked between 105 and 109 degrees. The peak heat index ranged from 105 degrees at Carbondale to 109 degrees at the Williamson County airport. The heat occurred under a brisk southwest wind flow between high pressure over the central Gulf coast and low pressure over the upper Great Lakes.

A large upper ridge prevailed across the region from mid-June through the end of the month resulting in very hot and humid conditions across the Mid-South. The heat was most intense on June 12th and 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index readings climbed to 110 degrees or greater.

Prolonged southwest flow and upper ridging lead to a period of temperatures in the mid to upper 90s with dewpoints in the low to mid 70s. Resulting heat index values rose to the mid to upper 100s across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105F on August 9th, locally up to 110F.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record high temperature set at Hoquiam airport of 82 degrees broke the old record of 75 degrees in 2002.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record high temperature of 85 degrees broke the previous record of 72 degrees in 1974.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record high temperature of 80 degrees broke the old record of 71 degrees set in 2015.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hazardous levels of heat and humidity occurred on the 1st. Afternoon heat indices peaked between 105 and 113 degrees. The peak heat index ranged from 106 degrees at Doniphan in Ripley County to 113 degrees at the Perryville airport in Perry County. The heat occurred under a brisk southwest wind flow between high pressure over the central Gulf coast and low pressure over the upper Great Lakes.

Another round of hazardous heat and humidity occurred, affecting all but the southeast corner from Massac to Hardin County. Afternoon heat indices peaked around 105 degrees. Specific readings included 106 at Marion, 109 at Mount Vernon, and 108 at Carmi. The heat occurred under a strong southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front over the central Plains.

This heat event was more pronounced than the previous one in June. Dew points pooled ahead of a frontal boundary Tuesday afternoon, August 2nd. These dew points that rose into the 70s combined with actual temperatures in the mid to upper 90s to support heat indices in the 100 to 115 degree range for several hours during the afternoon and evening of Tuesday, August 2nd. At one point Tuesday afternoon, heat indices rose to 115 degrees at Hutchinson, 114 degrees at Granite Falls, and 112 degrees at both Redwood Falls and New Ulm. Just west of the Twin Cities, heat indices were highest near Buffalo which rose to 111 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several temperature gauges measured heat indices between 105 and 110 degrees during the afternoon and evening hours.

The peak heat index ranged from 106 degrees at Doniphan in Ripley County to 113 degrees at the Perryville airport in Perry County. Upper ridging was anchored from the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles southeast into the Lower Mississippi Valley on August 15th-16th, which resulted in very hot and humid conditions across much of the Four State Region allowing for afternoon temperatures to climb into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees. Very little mixing of dew points was noted across Southwest Arkansas through this period, with resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees both days. The passage of a weak surface front on the 17th resulted in slightly cooler conditions, and focused scattered showers and thunderstorms across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Afternoon temperatures climbed to near 102 degrees in Fort Smith during the afternoon of the 16th, and the heat index was near 105 degrees. A young boy was reportedly left in a vehicle in the driveway of a home, where he died in the heat.

Hot and humid air with highs in the 90s and dewpoints around 70 degrees set up across central and eastern South Dakota during the day Friday. This was just ahead of a front that was slowly migrating southeast, though the frontal passage brought little relief as temperatures on the north side of the front still topped out close to the century mark, with dewpoints remaining in the 60s. Morning lows both Friday and Saturday remained in the 70s for most of the area. A peak heat index value of 120 degrees was observed at weather stations in Mellette and Onaka, with over 70 weather stations in central, north central and northeast South Dakota reporting a heat index of 100 degrees or higher at some point during the day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A period of above normal temperatures and heat continued to affect portions of Western Washington at the end of August. Daytime high temperatures ranged from the mid 80s to mid 90s for the interior lowlands and mountain valley with upper 60s to upper 70s for the coast. Lows temperatures were in the upper 50s to mid 60s. Overall, this posed a moderate risk of heat related impacts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 89 degrees was set at the Seattle WFO, breaking the old record of 86 set in 1987.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another period of very warm weather affected Western Washington at the end of August, helping set a few new record maximum temperatures. In general, daytime high temperatures ranged from the mid 80s to low 90s for the interior lowlands and mountain valleys; 70s for the coast. Overnight low temperatures were in the low to mid 60s. This posed a moderate risk for heat related impacts, with isolated areas of high heat risk.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 89 degrees was set at the Seattle WFO, tying the old record of 89 set in 1916.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 88 was set at the Hoquiam airport, breaking the old record of 83 set in 1968.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper ridge was anchored over the Southern Plains on August 3rd, resulting in very hot and humid conditions in place across all of the Four State Region. As a result, afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s and lower 100s across East Texas, with resultant heat indices generally ranging from 105 to 107 degrees. While these hot conditions were again observed on the 4th, greater mixing of dew points correlated to slightly lower heat indices below 105 degrees across East Texas.

An upper-level ridge extended from the southwest US into the Lower Mississippi Valley. Meanwhile, surface dewpoints pooled across the Mid-South in advance of an approaching cold front resulting in high heat index values across east-central Arkansas and north Mississippi.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat index values reached or exceeded 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper ridge was anchored over the Southern Plains on August 3rd, resulting in very hot and humid conditions in place across all of the Four State Region. As a result, afternoon temperatures climbed into the upper 90s and lower 100s across East Texas, with resultant heat indices generally ranging from 105 to 107 degrees. While these hot conditions were again observed on the 4th, greater mixing of dew points correlated to slightly lower heat indices below 105 degrees across East Texas.

A strong ridge of high pressure expanded westward over California, bringing unseasonably hot temperatures to interior areas. Temperatures peaked in the 100s up to 110 deg on August 16. A heat advisory was issued for the late morning through evening hours covering all interior mountain zones, the southern Salinas Valley, and the East Bay interior valleys.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Livermore Coop site reached a daily max record of 107 degrees, besting the previous record of 105 deg set in 1951. Other cities in the zone reached the low to mid 100s.

CZ_NAME: MOUNTAINS OF SAN BENITO COUNTY AND INTERIOR MONTEREY COUNTY INCLUDING PINNACLES NATIONAL PARK
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure expanded westward over California, bringing unseasonably hot temperatures to interior areas. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Both Pinnacles NP and Parkfield recorded max temperature 107 degrees. Various other stations in the zone reported highs between 100 and 106 deg.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level ridging strengthened over the region in early August. Hot and humid conditions resulted in heat index values of 105 degrees or higher over parts of the Mid-South.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat index values reached or exceeded 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper-level ridging strengthened over the region in early August. Hot and humid conditions resulted in heat index values of 105 degrees or higher over parts of the Mid-South.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Afternoon heat index values reached or exceeded  105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered over the Desert Southwest expanded over the Pacific Northwest bringing a brief hot spell to the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures on the 17th were in the upper 80s to over 100 degrees. For example, the high temperature at RAWS in Dodson (DSRO3) was 105.  Overnight temperatures were quite warm with lows in the 60s to low 70s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered over the Desert Southwest expanded over the Pacific Northwest bringing a brief hot spell to the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures on the 17th were in the 90s to around 100 degrees. For example, the high temperature at the Parkdale agrimet (PARO3) was 99 degrees. Overnight temperatures were quite warm with lows in the 60s to low 70s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered over the Desert Southwest expanded over the Pacific Northwest bringing a brief hot spell to the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures on the 17th were in the upper 80s to upper 90s. Overnight temperatures were quite warm with lows in the 60s  to mid 70s with cooler locations in the low valleys of the Cascade Foothills.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper ridging was anchored from the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles southeast into the Lower Mississippi Valley on August 15th-16th, which resulted in very hot and humid conditions across much of the Four State Region allowing for afternoon temperatures to climb into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees. Very little mixing of dew points was noted across portions of Northern Louisiana through this period, with resultant heat indices ranging from 105-110 degrees both days. The passage of a weak surface front on the 17th resulted in slightly cooler conditions, and focused scattered showers and thunderstorms across the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered over the Desert Southwest expanded over the Pacific Northwest bringing a brief hot spell to the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures on the 17th were in the mid to upper 90s. For example, the high temperature at Southwest Washington Regional Airport (KKLS) was 97 degrees. Overnight temperatures were quite warm with lows in the mid 60s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered over the Desert Southwest expanded over the Pacific Northwest bringing a brief hot spell to the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures on the 17th were in the mid 90s to 100 degrees. For example, the high temperature at Portland International Airport (KPDX) was 97 degrees, while Portland-Hillsboro had a high of 100 degrees. Overnight temperatures were quite warm with lows in the 60s with the urban areas remaining the warmest.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered over the Desert Southwest expanded over the Pacific Northwest bringing a brief hot spell to the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures on the 17th were in the mid to upper 90s. For example, the high temperature at McNary Field in Salem (KSLE) was 95 degrees. Mesonet stations in the area had high temperatures in the upper 90s. Overnight temperatures were quite warm with lows in the 60s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered over the Desert Southwest expanded over the Pacific Northwest bringing a brief hot spell to the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures on the 17th were in the mid to upper 90s. For example, the high temperature at Mahlon Sweet Field (KEUG) was 97 degrees. Overnight temperatures were quite warm with lows in the 60s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Upper ridging was anchored from the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles southeast into the Lower Mississippi Valley on August 15th-16th, which resulted in very hot and humid conditions across much of the Four State Region allowing for afternoon temperatures to climb into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees. Very little mixing of dew points was noted across North Louisiana through this period, with resultant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees both days. A weak surface front drifted south across North Louisiana on the 17th, which resulted in compressional warming along and just south of the front. Thus, temperatures climbed into the upper 90s to lower 100s, and when combined with the humidity, resulted in heat indices again ranging from 105-109 degrees. This front also focused scattered showers and thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon, with cooler conditions observed on the 18th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures on the 17th were in the upper 90s to 107 degrees. For example, the high temperature at Ken Jernstedt Airfield was 100 degrees. Overnight temperatures were quite warm with lows in the 60s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure expanded into the region bringing a very warm air mass. High temperatures peaked near 100 degrees on the 7th in portions of the Willamette Valley and through the Columbia River Gorge.  This was a brief event however as high temperatures were in the 80s in the days immediately following. One suspected heat related fatality occurred in Multnomah County on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures were generally in the mid 90s to around 100 degrees. McNary Field (KSLE) had a high of 100 degrees.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the southern United States during early August. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures near 100 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across portions of eastern Oklahoma on the 5th. At least four people were treated for heat-related illness in Tulsa.

Hot and humid air with highs in the 90s and dewpoints around 70 degrees set up across central and eastern South Dakota during the day Friday. This was just ahead of a front that was slowly migrating southeast, though the frontal passage brought little relief as temperatures on the north side of the front still topped out close to the century mark, with dewpoints remaining in the 60s. Morning lows both Friday and Saturday remained in the 70s for most of the area. A peak heat index value of 120 degrees was observed at weather stations in Mellette and Onaka, with over 70 weather stations in central, north central and northeast South Dakota reporting a heat index of 100 degrees or higher at some point during the day.

This was just ahead of a front that was slowly migrating southeast, though the frontal passage brought little relief as temperatures on the north side of the front still topped out close to the century mark, with dewpoints remaining in the 60s. A peak heat index value of 120 degrees was observed at weather stations in Mellette and Onaka, with over 70 weather stations in central, north central and northeast South Dakota reporting a heat index of 100 degrees or higher at some point during the day.

Upper ridging was anchored from the Texas and Oklahoma Panhandles southeast into the Lower Mississippi Valley on August 15th-16th, which resulted in very hot and humid conditions across much of the Four State Region allowing for afternoon temperatures to climb into the upper 90s to near 100 degrees. Very little mixing of dew points was noted across North Louisiana through this period, with resultant heat indices ranging from 105-109 degrees both days. A weak surface front drifted south across North Louisiana on the 17th, which resulted in compressional warming along and just south of the front. Thus, temperatures climbed into the upper 90s to lower 100s, and when combined with the humidity, resulted in heat indices again ranging from 105-109 degrees. This front also focused scattered showers and thunderstorms across the area during the afternoon, with cooler conditions observed on the 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the southern United States during early August. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures near 100 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across portions of eastern Oklahoma on the 5th. At least four people were treated for heat-related illness in Tulsa.
