A prolonged period of hot and humid weather occurred across eastern New York during the second half of July. Both the Albany and Poughkeepsie climate sites had a stretch of six consecutive days with high temperatures of 90 degrees Fahrenheit or above spanning July 19 to July 24. The addition of humidity led to heat indices peaking between 95 and 103 degrees during the afternoon hours across the Hudson Valley on July 20, 21, 23 and 24. The heat prompted the opening of cooling centers throughout the region to assist those that needed relief.

A dome of high pressure built across the Upper Midwest during the late weekend of June 19th. Heat indices surpassed 100 degrees in several areas of the Twin Cities, and across west central Minnesota where the index approached 105 degrees for several hours on Sunday. The highest heat index value was 105 degrees at Granite Falls Sunday afternoon, with 104 degrees at the Crystal airport. Heat indices were actually higher on Monday due to limited cooling the night before and lasted longer in the metro area due to the heat island effect. The highest heat index values outside the metro area was 108 degrees at Redwood Falls. In the Twin Cities, Crystal airport once again was the highest with 108 degrees by late afternoon. There were other higher heat indices across the area, but these were uncontrolled private weather stations that aren't certified as official.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local airport observations indicated that heat indices rose above 100 degrees by mid afternoon, and kept around 100 degrees for several hours before dropping into the 90s by 7 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent upper level ridge of high pressure moved over the region and persisted through the end of July and the first of August. Across the region, multiple areas in the lower elevations reached critical thresholds for heat risk, while many mountain zones saw consecutive days with high temperatures exceeding 95 degrees Fahrenheit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk values at the Yakima Airport GHCN site recorded several days between July 27th through the 31st of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent upper level ridge of high pressure moved over the region and persisted through the end of July and the first of August. Across the region, multiple areas in the lower elevations reached critical thresholds for heat risk, while many mountain zones saw consecutive days with high temperatures exceeding 95 degrees Fahrenheit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several RAWS stations across the zone recorded consecutive maximum daily high temperatures of 100 degrees or greater from July 25th through the 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat and humidity combined to produce heat indices in excess of 105 degrees during the afternoons of the 11th and 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: First responders responded to several heat related illnesses.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A stubborn area of high pressure remained over the region for the second half of the month, leading to an extended period of oppressive heat across much of the region. Several record highs were set as temperatures reached 105-110+ degrees in many areas.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dozens of heat related illnesses were reported over the course of this extended heat wave, with over 50 people transported to hospitals due to the severity of their symptoms.

The only reported high temperature was 96 degrees.  On 07/28/22, the only reported low temperature was 56 degrees. The only reported high temperature was 96 degrees.  On 07/29/22, the only reported low temperature was 56 degrees. The only reported high temperature was 99 degrees.  On 07/30/22, the only reported low temperature was 58 degrees. The only reported high temperature was 97 degrees.  On 07/31/22, the only reported low temperature was 55 degrees. The only reported high temperature was 93 degrees.

Mount Shasta City recorded records highs of 100 degrees on the 25th, 100 degrees on the 27th , 105 degrees on the 28th, 106 degrees on the 29th, and 100 degrees on the 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topped 110 degrees across most of western Kentucky in the afternoon. Peak heat indices ranged from 109 at Marion to 113 at Paducah and 115 at Henderson. A hot and humid southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front brought temperatures up to the mid 90's. Dew points were exceptionally high, with readings in the lower 80's at many stations. Early morning temperatures were quite warm. Paducah broke a daily warm low temperature record of 80 degrees.

A prolonged heat wave gripped most of western Kentucky for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 103 to 119 degrees. The exception was the Owensboro and Henderson area, where the dangerous levels of heat lasted only from the 4th until the 6th. The hottest days in western Kentucky were the 5th and 6th, when the heat index peaked between 109 and 119 at all mesonet and airport sites. Local Paducah hospitals reported an increase in emergency room visits for heat-related illnesses. A couple of dozen heat illnesses were reported, including heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke. A Salvation Army cooling center in Paducah reported an increase in visits. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared to near 100 degrees. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Paducah set a daily record warm low temperature of 80 degrees on the 6th. Paducah achieved four straight days of 110-degree plus heat indices from July 5-8, which was the first occurrence of this since 1987.

Heat index values reached 105 degrees or higher in a few locations of northwest Alabama during the late morning to midday hours before thunderstorms and cooler outflow moved into the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached and exceeded 105 degrees for up to three hours hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105-109 degrees during the afternoon hours in north central and northwest Alabama. Temperatures in the middle 90s combined with dew points in the middle to upper 70s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached 105-109 degrees for several hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dome of high pressure built across the Upper Midwest during the late weekend of June 19th. Heat indices surpassed 100 degrees in several areas of the Twin Cities, and across west central Minnesota where the index approached 105 degrees for several hours on Sunday. The highest heat index value was 105 degrees at Granite Falls Sunday afternoon, with 104 degrees at the Crystal airport. Heat indices were actually higher on Monday due to limited cooling the night before and lasted longer in the metro area due to the heat island effect. The highest heat index values outside the metro area was 108 degrees at Redwood Falls. In the Twin Cities, Crystal airport once again was the highest with 108 degrees by late afternoon. There were other higher heat indices across the area, but these were uncontrolled private weather stations that aren't certified as official.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local airports and other reporting stations measured heat indices near 105 degrees from the early afternoon, through the early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of hot and humid weather occurred across eastern New York during the second half of July. Both the Albany and Poughkeepsie climate sites had a stretch of six consecutive days with high temperatures of 90 degrees Fahrenheit or above spanning July 19 to July 24. The addition of humidity led to heat indices peaking between 95 and 103 degrees during the afternoon hours across the Hudson Valley on July 20, 21, 23 and 24. The heat prompted the opening of cooling centers throughout the region to assist those that needed relief.

A strong ridge of high pressure built across the Pacific Northwest at the end of July, making for well-above normal temperatures for most of Western Washington. Afternoon high temperatures in the interior lowlands soared into the 90s, with little relief during the overnight periods with lows in the 60s. This brought about a high probability of heat-related impacts to the area, especially those without an adequate means of cooling and/or hydration. Towards the beginning of August, the return to onshore flow from the Pacific brought about a relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot weather affected the Northern Interior of Western Washington. A record high temperature of 90 was set at the Bellingham airport the afternoon of July 26. This broke the previous record of 86 degrees set back in 1971 and 1988.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A long stretch of hot weather continued to impact the Southwest Interior through the end of the month. Another record high temperature of 99 degrees was set at the Olympia airport the afternoon of July 30th. This broke the previous record of 97 degrees set in 1965.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot weather continued to affect the Seattle metro area through the end of the month. Another record high temperature of 95 degrees was set at Sea-Tac airport on the afternoon of the 31. This broke the old record of 94 set back in 2015.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dome of high pressure built across the Upper Midwest during the late weekend of June 19th. Heat indices surpassed 100 degrees in several areas of the Twin Cities, and across west central Minnesota where the index approached 105 degrees for several hours on Sunday. The highest heat index value was 105 degrees at Granite Falls Sunday afternoon, with 104 degrees at the Crystal airport. Heat indices were actually higher on Monday due to limited cooling the night before and lasted longer in the metro area due to the heat island effect. The highest heat index values outside the metro area was 108 degrees at Redwood Falls. In the Twin Cities, Crystal airport once again was the highest with 108 degrees by late afternoon. There were other higher heat indices across the area, but these were uncontrolled private weather stations that aren't certified as official.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local airport observations indicated that heat indices rose above 100 degrees by mid afternoon, and kept around 100 degrees for several hours before dropping into the 90s by 7 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere restrengthened over the southern United States during late July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching 100 to 110 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 24th through 28th. There were at least twenty heat-related medical calls in the City of Tulsa during this period.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: On 07/25/22, reported low temperatures in this zone ranged from 60 to 64 degrees.  Reported high temperatures ranged from 104 to 108 degrees. On 07/26/22, reported low temperatures ranged from 62 to 76 degrees. Reported high temperatures ranged from 101 to 109 degrees. On 07/27/22, reported low temperatures ranged from 67 to 71 degrees. Reported high temperatures ranged from 105 to 111 degrees.  On 07/28/22, reported low temperatures ranged from 65 to 67 degrees. Reported high temperatures ranged from 109 to 112 degrees. EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topped 110 degrees across southeast Missouri in the afternoon. Peak heat indices ranged from 110 at Van Buren in Carter County to 114 at Poplar Bluff and 117 at Perryville. A hot and humid southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front brought temperatures up to the mid to upper 90's. Dew points were exceptionally high, with readings in the lower 80's at most stations. Early morning low temperatures were quite warm. Both Poplar Bluff and Cape Girardeau broke daily warm low temperature records. The low was 78 at Poplar Bluff and 79 at Cape Girardeau.

A prolonged heat wave gripped most of western Kentucky for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 103 to 119 degrees. The exception was the Owensboro and Henderson area, where the dangerous levels of heat lasted only from the 4th until the 6th. The hottest days in western Kentucky were the 5th and 6th, when the heat index peaked between 109 and 119 at all mesonet and airport sites. Local Paducah hospitals reported an increase in emergency room visits for heat-related illnesses. A couple of dozen heat illnesses were reported, including heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke. A Salvation Army cooling center in Paducah reported an increase in visits. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared to near 100 degrees. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Paducah set a daily record warm low temperature of 80 degrees on the 6th. Paducah achieved four straight days of 110-degree plus heat indices from July 5-8, which was the first occurrence of this since 1987.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of hot and humid weather occurred across eastern New York during the second half of July. Both the Albany and Poughkeepsie climate sites had a stretch of six consecutive days with high temperatures of 90 degrees Fahrenheit or above spanning July 19 to July 24. The addition of humidity led to heat indices peaking between 95 and 103 degrees during the afternoon hours across the Hudson Valley on July 20, 21, 23 and 24. The heat prompted the opening of cooling centers throughout the region to assist those that needed relief.

A period of hot and humid weather led to heat indices peaking in the 95 to 102 degree range across portions of southern Vermont during the period of July 20-24, 2022. The Town of Brattleboro issued a heat advisory for the area, urging everyone to drink plenty of water, wear light clothing and stay out of the heat as much as possible. Cooling centers also opened across town.

A strong ridge of high pressure built across the Pacific Northwest at the end of July, making for well-above normal temperatures for most of Western Washington. Afternoon high temperatures in the interior lowlands soared into the 90s, with little relief during the overnight periods with lows in the 60s. This brought about a high probability of heat-related impacts to the area, especially those without an adequate means of cooling and/or hydration. Towards the beginning of August, the return to onshore flow from the Pacific brought about a relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An extended period of hot weather affected the Bremerton area. A record high temperature of 95 degrees was set in Bremerton on the afternoon of July 29.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of hot and humid weather occurred across northwestern Connecticut during the second half of July. Heat indices peaked between 95 and 103 degrees during the afternoon hours on July 20, 21, 23 and 24. Governor Ned Lamont activated Connecticut's extreme hot weather protocol from July 19 to July 24 which allowed state agencies, municipalities and others to coordinate with United Way 2-1-1 to ensure information on cooling centers was available statewide.

A strong ridge of high pressure built across the Pacific Northwest at the end of July, making for well-above normal temperatures for most of Western Washington. Afternoon high temperatures in the interior lowlands soared into the 90s, with little relief during the overnight periods with lows in the 60s. This brought about a high probability of heat-related impacts to the area, especially those without an adequate means of cooling and/or hydration. Towards the beginning of August, the return to onshore flow from the Pacific brought about a relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An observation site in Monroe recorded a record high temperature of 90 degrees on the afternoon of the 31.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures in the 90s and lower 100s, along with dew point temperatures in the 60s and lower 70s, produced heat indices of 100 to near 110 degrees during the afternoon of July 18th. Some activities were postponed or canceled due to the heat. Some of the highest heat indices include 109 degrees in Ridgeview, 108 degrees in Hayes and McLaughlin, and 107 degrees in Pierre.

A dome of high pressure built across the Upper Midwest during the late weekend of June 19th. Heat indices surpassed 100 degrees in several areas of the Twin Cities, and across west central Minnesota where the index approached 105 degrees for several hours on Sunday. The highest heat index value was 105 degrees at Granite Falls Sunday afternoon, with 104 degrees at the Crystal airport. Heat indices were actually higher on Monday due to limited cooling the night before and lasted longer in the metro area due to the heat island effect. The highest heat index values outside the metro area was 108 degrees at Redwood Falls. In the Twin Cities, Crystal airport once again was the highest with 108 degrees by late afternoon. There were other higher heat indices across the area, but these were uncontrolled private weather stations that aren't certified as official.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local airports and other reporting stations measured heat indices above 105 degrees from the early afternoon, through the early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105-109 degrees on successive days with low temperatures in the middle to upper 70s at times in urban areas. High temperatures were in the middle to upper 90s, reaching 100 at Huntsville on the 5th and 101 at Muscle Shoals on the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values peaked at 105 to 109 degrees on successive days with low temperatures around 75 degrees.  High temperatures were in the middle to upper 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105-109 degrees on successive days with low temperatures in the middle to upper 70s at times in urban areas. High temperatures were in the middle to upper 90s, reaching 100 at Huntsville on the 5th and 101 at Muscle Shoals on the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached up to 110 on the 7th and 8th and up to 114 on the 9th in Muscle Shoals. High temperatures were in the upper 90s to around 100, peaking at 101 at Muscle Shoals on the 8th. Low temperatures were only in the middle 70s. Thunderstorms and showers in the area finally broke up the heat during the late afternoon of the 9th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topped 110 degrees across southeast Missouri in the afternoon. Peak heat indices ranged from 110 at Van Buren in Carter County to 114 at Poplar Bluff and 117 at Perryville. A hot and humid southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front brought temperatures up to the mid to upper 90's. Dew points were exceptionally high, with readings in the lower 80's at most stations. Early morning low temperatures were quite warm. Both Poplar Bluff and Cape Girardeau broke daily warm low temperature records. The low was 78 at Poplar Bluff and 79 at Cape Girardeau.

Another period of hazardous heat occurred across southwest Indiana. Heat indices peaked around 105 degrees on the 22nd, 23rd, and 24th. The peak heat index at Evansville was 105 on the 22nd, 105 on the 23rd, and 107 on the 24th. Another large 500 mb high became stubbornly persistent across the southern states, from the Four Corners region to the Southeast. Underneath this high, daily high temperatures were in the mid 90's. Overnight lows were mostly in the mid 70's.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dome of high pressure built across the Upper Midwest during the late weekend of June 19th. Heat indices surpassed 100 degrees in several areas of the Twin Cities, and across west central Minnesota where the index approached 105 degrees for several hours on Sunday. The highest heat index value was 105 degrees at Granite Falls Sunday afternoon, with 104 degrees at the Crystal airport. Heat indices were actually higher on Monday due to limited cooling the night before and lasted longer in the metro area due to the heat island effect. The highest heat index values outside the metro area was 108 degrees at Redwood Falls. In the Twin Cities, Crystal airport once again was the highest with 108 degrees by late afternoon. There were other higher heat indices across the area, but these were uncontrolled private weather stations that aren't certified as official.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local airport observations indicated that heat indices rose above 100 degrees by mid afternoon, and kept around 100 degrees for several hours before dropping into the 90s by 7 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105-109 degrees on successive days with low temperatures in the middle to upper 70s at times in urban areas. High temperatures were in the middle to upper 90s, reaching 100 at Huntsville on the 5th and 101 at Muscle Shoals on the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached up to 110 on the 7th and 111 on the 8th at the Huntsville International Airport. High temperatures were in the upper 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105 to 109 degrees during the afternoon hours on the 5th through the 8th.  In Fayetteville, in Lincoln County, the heat index peaked at 110 degrees on the 7th. High temperatures were in the middle to upper 90s. Overnight lows were only in the lower to middle 70s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105 to 109 degrees during the afternoon hours. In Fayetteville, the heat index peaked at 110 degrees on the 7th for one to two hours (See Excessive Heat entry). High temperatures were in the middle to upper 90s. Overnight lows were only in the lower to middle 70s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another period of hazardous heat occurred across southwest Indiana. Heat indices peaked around 105 degrees on the 22nd, 23rd, and 24th. The peak heat index at Evansville was 105 on the 22nd, 105 on the 23rd, and 107 on the 24th. Another large 500 mb high became stubbornly persistent across the southern states, from the Four Corners region to the Southeast. Underneath this high, daily high temperatures were in the mid 90's. Overnight lows were mostly in the mid 70's.

Another period of hazardous heat occurred across western Kentucky. Heat indices peaked around 105 degrees along and north of a line from Madisonville to Paducah on the 22nd. Heat indices peaked around 105 degrees everywhere on the 23rd and 24th. The peak heat index at Paducah was 106 on the 22nd, 104 on the 23rd, and 108 on the 24th. Another large 500 mb high became stubbornly persistent across the southern states, from the Four Corners region to the Southeast. Underneath this high, daily high temperatures were in the mid 90's. Overnight lows were mostly in the mid 70's.

A dome of high pressure built across the Upper Midwest during the late weekend of June 19th. Heat indices surpassed 100 degrees in several areas of the Twin Cities, and across west central Minnesota where the index approached 105 degrees for several hours on Sunday. The highest heat index value was 105 degrees at Granite Falls Sunday afternoon, with 104 degrees at the Crystal airport. Heat indices were actually higher on Monday due to limited cooling the night before and lasted longer in the metro area due to the heat island effect. The highest heat index values outside the metro area was 108 degrees at Redwood Falls. In the Twin Cities, Crystal airport once again was the highest with 108 degrees by late afternoon. There were other higher heat indices across the area, but these were uncontrolled private weather stations that aren't certified as official.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local airport observations indicated that heat indices rose above 105 degrees by the early afternoon, and kept around 105 degrees for several hours before dropping into the 90s by 6 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures in the 90s and lower 100s, along with dew point temperatures in the 60s and lower 70s, produced heat indices of 100 to near 110 degrees during the afternoon of July 18th. Some activities were postponed or canceled due to the heat. Some of the highest heat indices include 109 degrees in Ridgeview, 108 degrees in Hayes and McLaughlin, and 107 degrees in Pierre.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another episode of hazardous heat impacted most of southeast Missouri. Peak heat indices on the afternoons of the 26th and 27th were around 105 degrees. Hot and humid southwest winds persisted ahead of a cold front as it moved east from the Plains toward the Mississippi Valley. Actual high temperatures were in the lower 90's.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Excessive heat occurred across the Coachella Valley and the San Diego County Deserts on July 21st and 22nd with temperatures exceeding 110 degrees in several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive heat occurred in the San Diego County Dserts on July 21st, when Ocotillo Wells recorded a high temperature of 117 degrees and Borrego Springs recorded a high of 109. Similar temperatures occurred on the 22nd, when Ocotillo Wells recorded a high of 117 degrees and Borrego Springs topped out at 111 degrees.

Similar temperatures occurred on the 22nd, when Palm Springs recorded a high of 113 degrees and Thermal topped out at 111 degrees.

A prolonged heat wave gripped most of western Kentucky for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 103 to 119 degrees. The exception was the Owensboro and Henderson area, where the dangerous levels of heat lasted only from the 4th until the 6th. The hottest days in western Kentucky were the 5th and 6th, when the heat index peaked between 109 and 119 at all mesonet and airport sites. Local Paducah hospitals reported an increase in emergency room visits for heat-related illnesses. A couple of dozen heat illnesses were reported, including heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke. A Salvation Army cooling center in Paducah reported an increase in visits. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared to near 100 degrees. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Paducah set a daily record warm low temperature of 80 degrees on the 6th. Paducah achieved four straight days of 110-degree plus heat indices from July 5-8, which was the first occurrence of this since 1987.
Hot and humid conditions developed across northwest Indiana during the afternoon of July 5th.  High temperatures were in the mid 90s and afternoon peak heat indices were around 105 degrees.

Temperatures and heat indices were cooler across far northeast Illinois and near Lake Michigan.

A baby died in a car in Upper Saint Clair after being left in a hot car for several hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 3 month old male died after being left several hours in a hot car along Fort Couch Road in Upper Saint Clair, PA. The maximum high temperature at KAGC (11 miles from the incident) was 92F; heat index for the day was close to 100 degrees. Article: https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/3-month-old-dies-left-parents-car-several-hours-pennsylvania-police-sa-rcna34139.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High dewpoint temperatures combined with very hot daytime high temperatures on July 20th, resulting in heat index values exceeding 111 degrees in Hidalgo, Starr, and Zapata Counties during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This event is based largely on observed heat index values across Southern Hidalgo County and Zapata County. Both counties saw heat indices top out above 111 degrees for several hours. Given the higher heat index values in both Hidalgo and Zapata Counties, it is inferred that Starr County also experienced heat indices in excess of 111 degrees for at least two hours. The Falcon Lake RAWS site recorded values technically reaching Excessive Heat criteria, but this observation site has a history of running notably higher than surrounding areas. Additionally, the Texas Mesonet site in La Gloria recorded a heat index of 111 between 3:50PM CDT and 4:20PM CDT. No heat-related injuries or fatalities were reported as of this writing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High dewpoint temperatures combined with very hot daytime high temperatures on July 20th, resulting in heat index values exceeding 111 degrees in Hidalgo, Starr, and Zapata Counties during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The McAllen Airport ASOS site first recorded heat index values reaching or exceeding 111 degrees around 1:30PM CDT. Heat index values then remained above 111 degrees through 4:30PM CDT, topping out around 116 degrees at 2:53PM CDT. Edinburg International Airport also observed heat index values of 111 degrees from 1:55PM CDT through 5:15PM CDT and briefly topped out at 113 degrees at 3:35PM CDT. No heat-related injuries or fatalities were reported as of this writing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure centered near the four corners area built westward into California and strengthened over the area providing for a period of dangerous heat over the San Joaquin Valley, lower Sierra foothills and the Kern River Valley during the afternoon hours.  Daytime highs generally ranged between 103 and 108 degrees each day except on July 17 when daytime generally ranged between 107 and 112 degrees.  The high weakened on July 21 and 22, but maximum temperatures remained in the triple digits at most locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 108 degrees on July 16 and July 18-20 and between 107 and 112 degrees on July 17.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat index values peaked at 111 degrees in Muscle Shoals and 110 in Huntsville on the 20th and 21st.  In Vinemont, the heat index peaked at 110 on the 21st.  Overnight low temperatures were in the middle to around 80. High temperatures were in the middle to upper 90s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached reached 105 to 109 degrees on the afternoon of the 20th and again during the midday through early afternoon hours of the 21st before higher heat was experienced during the late afternoon (see Excessive Heat entry). Overnight lows were only in the lower to middle 70s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105-109 degrees at most locations in southern middle Tennessee during the afternoon hours on the 20th and 21st.  The heat index peaked at 110 degrees at Fayetteville in Lincoln County for a few hours on the 20th.  High temperatures were in the middle 90s with lows in the middle to upper 70s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values reached 105-109 degrees at most locations in southern middle Tennessee during the afternoon hours on the 20th and 21st. High temperatures were in the middle 90s with lows in the middle to upper 70s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot conditions across the inland valleys and the deserts impacted Southern California during the middle of July. A wildfire southeast of Otay Lake in San Diego County burned around 100 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive heat impacted the lower deserts July 15-17. High temperatures ranged from 112-116 in the Coachella Valley including 116 at Ocotillo Wells on July 15; temperatures of 115 to 118 on July 16, which was also the hottest day of the event; temperatures of 111 to 117 on July 17.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot conditions across the inland valleys and the deserts impacted Southern California during the middle of July. A wildfire southeast of Otay Lake in San Diego County burned around 100 acres.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot conditions impacted the Inland Empire July 15-17. High temperatures ranged from the lower-90s to mid-100s on July 15; temperatures in the mid-90s to mid-100s on July 16, including 105 recorded at San Jacinto; temperatures in the mid- to upper-90s to mid-100s on July 17.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A heat wave gripped southwest Indiana for a few days. From the 4th to the 6th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 101 to 112 degrees. The hottest day in southwest Indiana was the 5th, when the heat index peaked at 109 degrees at the Evansville airport.   During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures soared to near 100 degrees. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Evansville set a daily record warm low temperature of 80 degrees on the 6th.  The temperature hit 101 degrees in Evansville on July 5, marking the first time since 2012 the city broke the century mark.

Hot temperatures 5 degrees above normal were experienced across parts of southeast Arizona July 18. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for four individuals found in the desert, two on the Tohono O'odham Nation, one in east central Pima County and one in Cochise County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot high temperatures around 100 degrees, or 5 degrees above normal, occurred on July 18, causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found in the desert 30 miles northeast of Douglas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure resulted in above to well above normal temperatures across West Central Texas during the month of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The San Angelo Regional Airport recorded several record high temperatures well above 100 degrees during the month of July. Also, a record high temperature of 110 degrees was set on July 11th. Also, there were many record warm low temperatures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dome of high pressure built across the Upper Midwest during the late weekend of June 19th. Heat indices surpassed 100 degrees in several areas of the Twin Cities, and across west central Minnesota where the index approached 105 degrees for several hours on Sunday. The highest heat index value was 105 degrees at Granite Falls Sunday afternoon, with 104 degrees at the Crystal airport. Heat indices were actually higher on Monday due to limited cooling the night before and lasted longer in the metro area due to the heat island effect. The highest heat index values outside the metro area was 108 degrees at Redwood Falls. In the Twin Cities, Crystal airport once again was the highest with 108 degrees by late afternoon. There were other higher heat indices across the area, but these were uncontrolled private weather stations that aren't certified as official.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local airports and other reporting stations measured heat indices above 105 degrees from the early afternoon, through the early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High dewpoint temperatures combined with very hot daytime high temperatures on July 20th, resulting in heat index values exceeding 111 degrees in Hidalgo, Starr, and Zapata Counties during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Zapata Airport AWOS site first recorded heat index values reaching or exceeding 111 degrees around 2:55PM CDT. Heat index values then remained above 111 degrees through 7:55PM CDT, topping out around 115 degrees at 6:35PM CDT. No heat-related injuries or fatalities were reported as of this writing.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 101 and 106 degrees on July 11 and July 12.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged heat wave gripped southeast Missouri for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 103 to 119 degrees. The hottest day in southeast Missouri was the 5th, when the heat index peaked between 111 and 119 at all mesonet and airport sites. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared to near 100 degrees. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Both Cape Girardeau and Poplar Bluff  set a daily record warm low temperature of 78 degrees on the 6th. Both Cape Girardeau and Poplar Bluff reached an actual high temperature of 100 degrees on the 5th. The heat resulted in two fatalities at a home in Gideon in New Madrid County. A couple in their 50's both passed away in their home, primarily due to heat exposure. Three dogs were also found deceased. The house had no air conditioning and was not well-ventilated.

A prolonged heat wave gripped southeast Missouri for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 103 to 119 degrees. The hottest day in southeast Missouri was the 5th, when the heat index peaked between 111 and 119 at all mesonet and airport sites. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared to near 100 degrees. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Both Cape Girardeau and Poplar Bluff  set a daily record warm low temperature of 78 degrees on the 6th. Both Cape Girardeau and Poplar Bluff reached an actual high temperature of 100 degrees on the 5th. The heat resulted in two fatalities at a home in Gideon in New Madrid County. A couple in their 50's both passed away in their home, primarily due to heat exposure. Three dogs were also found deceased. The house had no air conditioning and was not well-ventilated.

A prolonged heat wave gripped most of western Kentucky for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 103 to 119 degrees. The exception was the Owensboro and Henderson area, where the dangerous levels of heat lasted only from the 4th until the 6th. The hottest days in western Kentucky were the 5th and 6th, when the heat index peaked between 109 and 119 at all mesonet and airport sites. Local Paducah hospitals reported an increase in emergency room visits for heat-related illnesses. A couple of dozen heat illnesses were reported, including heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke. A Salvation Army cooling center in Paducah reported an increase in visits. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared to near 100 degrees. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Paducah set a daily record warm low temperature of 80 degrees on the 6th. Paducah achieved four straight days of 110-degree plus heat indices from July 5-8, which was the first occurrence of this since 1987.

A dome of high pressure built across the Upper Midwest during the late weekend of June 19th. Heat indices surpassed 100 degrees in several areas of the Twin Cities, and across west central Minnesota where the index approached 105 degrees for several hours on Sunday. The highest heat index value was 105 degrees at Granite Falls Sunday afternoon, with 104 degrees at the Crystal airport. Heat indices were actually higher on Monday due to limited cooling the night before and lasted longer in the metro area due to the heat island effect. The highest heat index values outside the metro area was 108 degrees at Redwood Falls. In the Twin Cities, Crystal airport once again was the highest with 108 degrees by late afternoon. There were other higher heat indices across the area, but these were uncontrolled private weather stations that aren't certified as official.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local airport observations indicated that heat indices rose above 100 degrees by mid afternoon, and kept around 100 degrees for several hours before dropping into the 90s by 7 PM.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure resulted in above to well above normal temperatures across West Central Texas during the month of July.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Abilene Regional Airport recorded several record high temperatures well above 100 degrees during the month of July. There were three days, July 18th, July 19th and July 20th, when the record high temperature was 110 degrees. Also, there were many record warm low temperatures.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the south central United States during early July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures climbing into the 100 to 105 degree range, combined with high humidity, resulted in heat index values from 110 to 116 degrees across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 6th through the 8th. There were at least nineteen heat-related medical calls in the City of Tulsa during this period.

A large area of high pressure centered over the Great Basin on July 11 and July 12  provided for a period of dangerous heat across the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills, Sierra foothills and the Kern River Valley during the afternoon hours. Daytime high temperatures generally ranged from 101 to 106 Degrees on both days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 101 and 106 degrees on July 11 and July 12.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure centered near the four corners area built westward into California and strengthened over the area providing for a period of dangerous heat over the San Joaquin Valley, lower Sierra foothills and the Kern River Valley during the afternoon hours.  Daytime highs generally ranged between 103 and 108 degrees each day except on July 17 when daytime generally ranged between 107 and 112 degrees.  The high weakened on July 21 and 22, but maximum temperatures remained in the triple digits at most locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 108 degrees on July 16 and July 18-20 and between 107 and 112 degrees on July 17.

An anomalous ridge built over the Front Range area resulted in record heat approaching all-time values. High temperatures across the Nebraska Panhandle were in the triple digits after morning lows only dropped into the 70s. Chadron came within one degree Fahrenheit of the all-time high temperature.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scottsbluff Airport ASOS station (KBFF) measured an afternoon high temperature of 108 degrees Fahrenheit and came within two degrees of the all-time record. This was the 4th hottest day all-time for Scottsbluff. The heat index also exceeded 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

There were at least twenty heat-related medical calls in the City of Tulsa during this period.

A dome of high pressure built across the Upper Midwest during the late weekend of June 19th. Heat indices surpassed 100 degrees in several areas of the Twin Cities, and across west central Minnesota where the index approached 105 degrees for several hours on Sunday. The highest heat index value was 105 degrees at Granite Falls Sunday afternoon, with 104 degrees at the Crystal airport. Heat indices were actually higher on Monday due to limited cooling the night before and lasted longer in the metro area due to the heat island effect. The highest heat index values outside the metro area was 108 degrees at Redwood Falls. In the Twin Cities, Crystal airport once again was the highest with 108 degrees by late afternoon. There were other higher heat indices across the area, but these were uncontrolled private weather stations that aren't certified as official.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local airports and other reporting stations measured heat indices near 105 degrees from the afternoon, through the early evening.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE MOUNTAINS SOUTH OF HIGHWAY 198
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure centered over the Great Basin on July 11 and July 12  provided for a period of dangerous heat across the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills, Sierra foothills and the Kern River Valley during the afternoon hours. Daytime high temperatures generally ranged from 101 to 106 Degrees on both days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 101 and 106 degrees on July 11 and July 12.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure centered near the four corners area built westward into California and strengthened over the area providing for a period of dangerous heat over the San Joaquin Valley, lower Sierra foothills and the Kern River Valley during the afternoon hours.  Daytime highs generally ranged between 103 and 108 degrees each day except on July 17 when daytime generally ranged between 107 and 112 degrees.  The high weakened on July 21 and 22, but maximum temperatures remained in the triple digits at most locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 103 and 108 degrees on July 16 and July 18-20 and between 107 and 112 degrees on July 17.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged heat wave gripped southeast Missouri for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 103 to 119 degrees. The hottest day in southeast Missouri was the 5th, when the heat index peaked between 111 and 119 at all mesonet and airport sites. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared to near 100 degrees. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Both Cape Girardeau and Poplar Bluff  set a daily record warm low temperature of 78 degrees on the 6th. Both Cape Girardeau and Poplar Bluff reached an actual high temperature of 100 degrees on the 5th. The heat resulted in two fatalities at a home in Gideon in New Madrid County. A couple in their 50's both passed away in their home, primarily due to heat exposure. Three dogs were also found deceased. The house had no air conditioning and was not well-ventilated.

A prolonged heat wave gripped most of western Kentucky for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 103 to 119 degrees. The exception was the Owensboro and Henderson area, where the dangerous levels of heat lasted only from the 4th until the 6th. The hottest days in western Kentucky were the 5th and 6th, when the heat index peaked between 109 and 119 at all mesonet and airport sites. Local Paducah hospitals reported an increase in emergency room visits for heat-related illnesses. A couple of dozen heat illnesses were reported, including heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke. A Salvation Army cooling center in Paducah reported an increase in visits. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared to near 100 degrees. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Paducah set a daily record warm low temperature of 80 degrees on the 6th. Paducah achieved four straight days of 110-degree plus heat indices from July 5-8, which was the first occurrence of this since 1987.

An anomalous ridge built over the Front Range area resulted in record heat approaching all-time values. High temperatures across the Nebraska Panhandle were in the triple digits after morning lows only dropped into the 70s. Chadron came within one degree Fahrenheit of the all-time high temperature.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Chadron Airport ASOS station (KCDR) measured an afternoon high temperature of 111 degrees Fahrenheit and came within one degree of the all-time record. This was the 2nd hottest day all-time for Chadron. The heat index also reached 105 degrees Fahrenheit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomalous ridge built over the Front Range area resulted in record heat approaching all-time values. High temperatures across the Nebraska Panhandle were in the triple digits after morning lows only dropped into the 70s. Chadron came within one degree Fahrenheit of the all-time high temperature.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Alliance Airport ASOS station (KAIA) measured an afternoon high temperature of 105 degrees Fahrenheit with a heat index exceeding 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged heat wave gripped southeast Missouri for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 103 to 119 degrees. The hottest day in southeast Missouri was the 5th, when the heat index peaked between 111 and 119 at all mesonet and airport sites. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared to near 100 degrees. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Both Cape Girardeau and Poplar Bluff  set a daily record warm low temperature of 78 degrees on the 6th. Both Cape Girardeau and Poplar Bluff reached an actual high temperature of 100 degrees on the 5th. The heat resulted in two fatalities at a home in Gideon in New Madrid County. A couple in their 50's both passed away in their home, primarily due to heat exposure. Three dogs were also found deceased. The house had no air conditioning and was not well-ventilated.

Heat indices topped 110 degrees across most of western Kentucky in the afternoon. Peak heat indices ranged from 109 at Marion to 113 at Paducah and 115 at Henderson. A hot and humid southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front brought temperatures up to the mid 90's. Dew points were exceptionally high, with readings in the lower 80's at many stations. Early morning temperatures were quite warm. Paducah broke a daily warm low temperature record of 80 degrees.

A prolonged heat wave gripped most of western Kentucky for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 103 to 119 degrees. The exception was the Owensboro and Henderson area, where the dangerous levels of heat lasted only from the 4th until the 6th. The hottest days in western Kentucky were the 5th and 6th, when the heat index peaked between 109 and 119 at all mesonet and airport sites. Local Paducah hospitals reported an increase in emergency room visits for heat-related illnesses. A couple of dozen heat illnesses were reported, including heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke. A Salvation Army cooling center in Paducah reported an increase in visits. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared to near 100 degrees. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Paducah set a daily record warm low temperature of 80 degrees on the 6th. Paducah achieved four straight days of 110-degree plus heat indices from July 5-8, which was the first occurrence of this since 1987.

A prolonged period of hot and humid weather occurred across eastern New York during the second half of July. Both the Albany and Poughkeepsie climate sites had a stretch of six consecutive days with high temperatures of 90 degrees Fahrenheit or above spanning July 19 to July 24. The addition of humidity led to heat indices peaking between 95 and 103 degrees during the afternoon hours across the Hudson Valley on July 20, 21, 23 and 24. The heat prompted the opening of cooling centers throughout the region to assist those that needed relief.

A prolonged heatwave developed as strong high pressure formed over the Pacific Northwest. This event was most notable by it's duration.  High temperatures around 100 degrees persisted for a week for much of the northwest Oregon and southwest Washington, except the coast.  Heat indicies ranged from 95 to 105 degrees during the afternoons. This resulted in several suspected deaths related to the heat.  The heatwave lasted through the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Multnomah County Medical Examiner reported suspected deaths associated with the heat wave. One each on July 25th, 26th, 27th; two each on the 28th and 30th, all in Portland. A man drowned on the Sandy River on the 27th while paddle boarding. During the heatwave there were elevated numbers of heat related illnesses. For example on the 30th, Multnomah County reported 10 requests for Emergency/Urgent care. A typical summer day is zero to one. There was a cumulative of 63 heat illness, more than half of a typical summer. In another incident on July 25th, a man drowned while swimming at Henry Hagg Lake in Washington County.  Also in Washington County, a dog died from the heat when left in a car. Other suspected heat related deaths occurred July 28th and 29th in Clackamas County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged heatwave developed as strong high pressure formed over the Pacific Northwest. This event was most notable by it's duration. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four suspected heat related deaths occurred in Marion county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere restrengthened over the southern United States during late July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching 100 to 110 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 24th through 28th. There were at least twenty heat-related medical calls in the City of Tulsa during this period.

A dome of high pressure built across the Upper Midwest during the late weekend of June 19th. Heat indices surpassed 100 degrees in several areas of the Twin Cities, and across west central Minnesota where the index approached 105 degrees for several hours on Sunday. The highest heat index value was 105 degrees at Granite Falls Sunday afternoon, with 104 degrees at the Crystal airport. Heat indices were actually higher on Monday due to limited cooling the night before and lasted longer in the metro area due to the heat island effect. The highest heat index values outside the metro area was 108 degrees at Redwood Falls. In the Twin Cities, Crystal airport once again was the highest with 108 degrees by late afternoon. There were other higher heat indices across the area, but these were uncontrolled private weather stations that aren't certified as official.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local airports and other reporting stations measured heat indices above 105 degrees from the early afternoon, through the early evening.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index reached and exceeded 105 degrees for up to three hours in valley locations.

CZ_NAME: FOOTHILLS OF THE NORTHERN BLUE MOUNTAINS OF OREGON
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent upper level ridge of high pressure moved over the region and persisted through the end of July and the first of August. Across the region, multiple areas in the lower elevations reached critical thresholds for heat risk, while many mountain zones saw consecutive days with high temperatures exceeding 95 degrees Fahrenheit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk values at the The Pendleton and Milton Freewater GHCN recorded consecutive days between July 27th through July 31st of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk values at the Dallesport Airport GHCN site recorded consecutive days between July 26th through Aug. 1st of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomalous ridge built over the Front Range area resulted in record heat approaching all-time values. High temperatures across southeast Wyoming reached the upper 90s and even the triple digits in spots along the North Platte River valley. Cheyenne came within one degree Fahrenheit of the all-time high temperature.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cheyenne Airport ASOS station (KCYS) measured an afternoon high temperature of 99 degrees Fahrenheit and came within one degree of the all-time record. This was the 5th hottest day all-time in Cheyenne.

Cheyenne came within one degree Fahrenheit of the all-time high temperature.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Torrington Airport ASOS station (KTOR) measured an afternoon high temperature of 107 degrees Fahrenheit with a heat index exceeding 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

High pressure over interior northern California brought widespread moderate heat risk to the Sacramento Valley with areas of high to extreme heat risk in the northern Sacramento Valley and adjacent foothills. Triple digit temperatures were observed across much of the central to northern Sacramento Valley on July 28th and 29th with the hottest temperatures on July 28th. A new daily high temperature record was set in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: ASOS reported high temperature readings ranged from 106 to 113 degrees during the event. The warmest high temperatures were observed on the 28th and reached 113 at the Sims RAWS in the mountains of Shasta County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over interior northern California brought widespread moderate heat risk to the Sacramento Valley with areas of high to extreme heat risk in the northern Sacramento Valley and adjacent foothills. Triple digit temperatures were observed across much of the central to northern Sacramento Valley on July 28th and 29th with the hottest temperatures on July 28th. A new daily high temperature record was set in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: ASOS reported high temperature readings ranged from 106 to 109 degrees during the event. The warmest high temperatures were observed on the 28th and reached 109 in Fall River Mills in the mountains of northeastern Shasta County.

A new daily high temperature record was set in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: ASOS reported high temperature readings ranged from 100 to 106 degrees during the event in the northern portion of Zone 66.

CZ_NAME: MOUNTAINS SOUTHWESTERN SHASTA COUNTY TO WESTERN COLUSA COUNTY
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over interior northern California brought widespread moderate heat risk to the Sacramento Valley with areas of high to extreme heat risk in the northern Sacramento Valley and adjacent foothills. Triple digit temperatures were observed across much of the central to northern Sacramento Valley on July 28th and 29th with the hottest temperatures on July 28th. A new daily high temperature record was set in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: ASOS reported high temperature readings ranged from 103 to 106 degrees during the event in the northern portion of Zone 63.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over interior northern California brought widespread moderate heat risk to the Sacramento Valley with areas of high to extreme heat risk in the northern Sacramento Valley and adjacent foothills. Triple digit temperatures were observed across much of the central to northern Sacramento Valley on July 28th and 29th with the hottest temperatures on July 28th. A new daily high temperature record was set in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: ASOS reported high temperature readings ranged from 104 to 115 degrees during the event. The warmest high temperatures were observed on the 28th and reached 115 at the Redding Airport in the northern Sacramento Valley also setting a new record daily high temperature. Cooling centers were made available to the public in Redding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged period of hot and humid weather occurred across eastern New York during the second half of July. Both the Albany and Poughkeepsie climate sites had a stretch of six consecutive days with high temperatures of 90 degrees Fahrenheit or above spanning July 19 to July 24. The addition of humidity led to heat indices peaking between 95 and 103 degrees during the afternoon hours across the Hudson Valley on July 20, 21, 23 and 24. The heat prompted the opening of cooling centers throughout the region to assist those that needed relief.

A dome of high pressure built across the Upper Midwest during the late weekend of June 19th. Heat indices surpassed 100 degrees in several areas of the Twin Cities, and across west central Minnesota where the index approached 105 degrees for several hours on Sunday. The highest heat index value was 105 degrees at Granite Falls Sunday afternoon, with 104 degrees at the Crystal airport. Heat indices were actually higher on Monday due to limited cooling the night before and lasted longer in the metro area due to the heat island effect. The highest heat index values outside the metro area was 108 degrees at Redwood Falls. In the Twin Cities, Crystal airport once again was the highest with 108 degrees by late afternoon. There were other higher heat indices across the area, but these were uncontrolled private weather stations that aren't certified as official.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local airports and other reporting stations measured heat indices above 105 degrees from the early afternoon, through the early evening.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures in the 90s and lower 100s, along with dew point temperatures in the 60s and lower 70s, produced heat indices of 100 to near 110 degrees during the afternoon of July 18th. Some activities were postponed or canceled due to the heat. Some of the highest heat indices include 109 degrees in Ridgeview, 108 degrees in Hayes and McLaughlin, and 107 degrees in Pierre.

A potent upper level ridge of high pressure moved over the region and persisted through the end of July and the first of August. Across the region, multiple areas in the lower elevations reached critical thresholds for heat risk, while many mountain zones saw consecutive days with high temperatures exceeding 95 degrees Fahrenheit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Eden RAWS recorded consecutive maximum daily high temperatures of 95 degrees or greater from July 26th through the 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent upper level ridge of high pressure moved over the region and persisted through the end of July and the first of August. Across the region, multiple areas in the lower elevations reached critical thresholds for heat risk, while many mountain zones saw consecutive days with high temperatures exceeding 95 degrees Fahrenheit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Calculated heat risk values at the Dallesport Airport GHCN site recorded consecutive days between July 26th through Aug. 1st of temperatures that met or exceeded excessive heat warning criteria.

CZ_NAME: EAST SLOPES OF THE WASHINGTON CASCADES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent upper level ridge of high pressure moved over the region and persisted through the end of July and the first of August. Across the region, multiple areas in the lower elevations reached critical thresholds for heat risk, while many mountain zones saw consecutive days with high temperatures exceeding 95 degrees Fahrenheit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several RAWS stations across the zone recorded consecutive maximum daily high temperatures of 95 degrees or greater from July 25th through the 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topped 110 degrees across most of western Kentucky in the afternoon. Peak heat indices ranged from 109 at Marion to 113 at Paducah and 115 at Henderson. A hot and humid southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front brought temperatures up to the mid 90's. Dew points were exceptionally high, with readings in the lower 80's at many stations. Early morning temperatures were quite warm. Paducah broke a daily warm low temperature record of 80 degrees.

A prolonged heat wave gripped most of western Kentucky for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 103 to 119 degrees. The exception was the Owensboro and Henderson area, where the dangerous levels of heat lasted only from the 4th until the 6th. The hottest days in western Kentucky were the 5th and 6th, when the heat index peaked between 109 and 119 at all mesonet and airport sites. Local Paducah hospitals reported an increase in emergency room visits for heat-related illnesses. A couple of dozen heat illnesses were reported, including heat cramps, heat exhaustion, and heat stroke. A Salvation Army cooling center in Paducah reported an increase in visits. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared to near 100 degrees. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Paducah set a daily record warm low temperature of 80 degrees on the 6th. Paducah achieved four straight days of 110-degree plus heat indices from July 5-8, which was the first occurrence of this since 1987.

A persistent upper level ridge spanning much of the Southern U.S. in mid July maintained hot temperatures across all of the Four State Region from July 12th through the 13th, with daytime temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower and middle 100s. When combined with the daytime humidity, oppressively hot conditions were observed as heat indices averaged between 105-109 degrees during the peak heating hours.

An expansive upper level ridge centered over the Southern Plains eastward into the lower Mississippi Valley in late July led to consecutive days of abnormally hot temperatures across all of the Four State Region, with daytime temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower 100s each afternoon. Wet soils from widespread rains that occurred during the 21st-22nd also did not allow for much mixing of dew points, with oppressively hot conditions observed as heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees each day during the peak heating hours.

An exceptionally hot summer really got going during the early to middle part of July as triple digit heat became the norm. Most of the region reached Heat Advisory criteria, and a good portion of the area met or exceeded Excessive Heat criteria at some point during this July stretch of hot weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices met or exceeded 105 on most afternoons from July 6 through July 31 across Eastland County.

Most of the region reached Heat Advisory criteria, and a good portion of the area met or exceeded Excessive Heat criteria at some point during this July stretch of hot weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices met or exceeded 105 on most afternoons from July 6 through July 31 across Bosque County.

Most of the region reached Heat Advisory criteria, and a good portion of the area met or exceeded Excessive Heat criteria at some point during this July stretch of hot weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The summer heat increased to Excessive Heat criteria with ambient temperatures near or above 105 degrees and/or heat index values near or above 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying upper level ridge spanning much of the Southern U.S. in early July led to excessively hot temperatures across all of the Four State Region on July 9th, with daytime temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower and middle 100s. When combined with the daytime humidity, oppressively hot conditions were observed as heat indices averaged between 110-115 degrees during the peak heating hours.

A persistent upper level ridge spanning much of the Southern U.S. in mid July maintained hot temperatures across all of the Four State Region from July 16th through the 18th, with daytime temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower and middle 100s. When combined with the daytime humidity, oppressively hot conditions were observed as heat indices averaged between 105-109 degrees during the peak heating hours.

An expansive upper level ridge centered over the Southern Plains eastward into the lower Mississippi Valley in late July led to consecutive days of abnormally hot temperatures across all of the Four State Region, with daytime temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower 100s each afternoon. Wet soils from widespread rains that occurred during the 21st-22nd also did not allow for much mixing of dew points, with oppressively hot conditions observed as heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees each day during the peak heating hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The final week of July a heat wave struck the Inland NW with an abundance of sunshine each day. High temperatures warmed into the 90s from the 24th through the 26th and|then upper 90s and triple digits from the 27th through the 31st. Temperatures across the region ranged from 112 to 96. Spokane Felts Field was one of the hottest locations in the area, reaching 105F on the 31st. Spokane airport achieved 100 degree or warmer four consecutive days, which tied for 2nd place for the longest consecutive 100+ degree day streak on record.  Thirteen daily records were broken across the Inland Northwest. DOH reported heat caused 224 emergency patients in Eastern Washington.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperature for the day was 110. An 88-year-old resident of a Wenatchee assisted-living facility went outside and fell on July 25.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperature for the day was 100. An 80-year-old woman who had emphysema and was living in her car died Monday in Omak.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in the lower 90s and heat index in the upper 90s led to a fatality.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: According to a police report a 3 year old girl let herself into a vehicle around 1 PM. Afternoon high temperatures rose into the lower 90s with heat index values in the upper 90s to around 100 degrees. The girl was found unresponsive and died on August 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass send heat indices soaring from 95 to 102 degrees across much of west and central Upper Michigan on the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The heat index peaked at 98 degrees at Chatham during the early afternoon of the 18th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High temperatures across the Nebraska Panhandle were in the triple digits after morning lows only dropped into the 70s. This was also the second consecutive day of hot temperatures across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Chadron Airport ASOS station (KCDR) measured an afternoon high temperature of 109 degrees Fahrenheit. This was tied for the 6th hottest day all-time for Chadron. The heat index also reached 105 degrees Fahrenheit.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices met or exceeded 105 on most afternoons from July 6 through July 31 across Henderson County.

A strengthening upper level ridge spanning much of the Southern U.S. in mid July led to excessively hot temperatures across all of the Four State Region from July 19th through the 21st, with daytime temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower 100s. A weak surface front that drifted south through Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas during the afternoon of the 21st resulted in compressional warming over McCurtain County, with even hotter temperatures observed as readings ranged from 103-105 degrees. When combined with the daytime humidity, oppressively hot conditions were observed as heat indices averaged between 110-115 degrees during the peak heating hours.

Most of the region reached Heat Advisory criteria, and a good portion of the area met or exceeded Excessive Heat criteria at some point during this July stretch of hot weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The summer heat increased to Excessive Heat criteria with ambient temperatures near or above 105 degrees and/or heat index values near or above 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying upper level ridge spanning much of the Southern U.S. in early July led to excessively hot temperatures across all of the Four State Region on July 9th, with daytime temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower and middle 100s. When combined with the daytime humidity, oppressively hot conditions were observed as heat indices averaged between 110-115 degrees during the peak heating hours.

A strengthening upper level ridge spanning much of the Southern U.S. in mid July led to excessively hot temperatures across all of the Four State Region from July 19th through the 21st, with daytime temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower 100s. A weak surface front that drifted south through Southeast Oklahoma and Southwest Arkansas during the afternoon of the 21st resulted in compressional warming over these areas, with even hotter temperatures observed as readings ranged from 101-105 degrees. When combined with the daytime humidity, oppressively hot conditions were observed as heat indices averaged between 110-115 degrees during the peak heating hours.

An expansive upper level ridge spanning much of the Southern U.S. in early July led to consecutive days of abnormally hot temperatures across all of the Four State Region, with daytime temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s to lower 100s each afternoon. Wet soils from near widespread rains back on the 2nd-3rd also did not allow for much mixing of dew points, with oppressively hot conditions observed as heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees each day during the peak heating hours.

Upper-level ridging over the area brought unseasonably warm and dry conditions over a extended period of time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record high temperature at Hoquiam Airport of 76, breaking the record of 74 in 1961.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A six-month old female infant died after being left in a vehicle.  Although limited details are available, it is assumed that the infant was left inside the vehicle sometime on the 26th when temperatures were in the lower to middle 90s. The infant was found the next morning around 0700 LST.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A six-month old female infant died after being left in a vehicle. Although limited details are available, it is assumed that the infant was left inside the vehicle sometime on the 26th when temperatures were in the lower to middle 90s. The infant was found the next morning around 0700 LST.

A persistent upper level ridge spanning much of the Southern U.S. in mid July maintained hot temperatures across parts of the Four State Region from July 11th through the 13th, with daytime temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower and middle 100s. When combined with the daytime humidity, oppressively hot conditions were observed as heat indices averaged between 105-109 degrees during the peak heating hours. Unfortunately, a heat-related fatality occurred around 2:15 pm on July 11th in the Kisatchie National Forest in Southern Natchitoches Parish when a 24 year old female suffered a heat stroke while performing an archaeological survey for the U.S. Forest Service near Forest Service Road #321 Bayou Camp Road off of Longleaf Vista, in what was her first day on the job.

A dome of high pressure built across the Upper Midwest during the late weekend of June 19th. Heat indices surpassed 100 degrees in several areas of the Twin Cities, and across west central Minnesota where the index approached 105 degrees for several hours on Sunday. The highest heat index value was 105 degrees at Granite Falls Sunday afternoon, with 104 degrees at the Crystal airport. Heat indices were actually higher on Monday due to limited cooling the night before and lasted longer in the metro area due to the heat island effect. The highest heat index values outside the metro area was 108 degrees at Redwood Falls. In the Twin Cities, Crystal airport once again was the highest with 108 degrees by late afternoon. There were other higher heat indices across the area, but these were uncontrolled private weather stations that aren't certified as official.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local airports and other reporting stations measured heat indices above 100 degrees from the early afternoon, through the early evening.

Most of the region reached Heat Advisory criteria, and a good portion of the area met or exceeded Excessive Heat criteria at some point during this July stretch of hot weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices met or exceeded 105 on most afternoons from July 6 through July 31 across Bell County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intensifying upper level ridge spanning much of the Southern U.S. in early July led to excessively hot temperatures across parts of the Four State Region on July 9th and 10th, with daytime temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower and middle 100s. When combined with the daytime humidity, oppressively hot conditions were observed as heat indices averaged between 110-115 degrees during the peak heating hours.

A persistent upper level ridge spanning much of the Southern U.S. in mid July maintained hot temperatures across parts of the Four State Region from July 11th through the 13th, with daytime temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower and middle 100s. When combined with the daytime humidity, oppressively hot conditions were observed as heat indices averaged between 105-109 degrees during the peak heating hours. Unfortunately, a heat-related fatality occurred around 2:15 pm on July 11th in the Kisatchie National Forest in Southern Natchitoches Parish when a 24 year old female suffered a heat stroke while performing an archaeological survey for the U.S. Forest Service near Forest Service Road #321 Bayou Camp Road off of Longleaf Vista, in what was her first day on the job.

An expansive upper level ridge spanning much of the Southern U.S. in early July led to consecutive days of abnormally hot temperatures across all of the Four State Region, with daytime temperatures climbing into the mid and upper 90s to lower 100s each afternoon. Wet soils from near widespread rains back on the 2nd-3rd also did not allow for much mixing of dew points, with oppressively hot conditions observed as heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees each day during the peak heating hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High temperatures across the Nebraska Panhandle were in the triple digits after morning lows only dropped into the 70s. This was also the second consecutive day of hot temperatures across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Alliance Airport ASOS station (KAIA) measured an afternoon high temperature of 104 degrees Fahrenheit. The heat index also exceeded 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High temperatures across the Nebraska Panhandle were in the triple digits after morning lows only dropped into the 70s. This was also the second consecutive day of hot temperatures across the region.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scottsbluff Airport ASOS station (KBFF) measured an afternoon high temperature of 106 degrees Fahrenheit. The heat index also exceeded 100 degrees Fahrenheit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent upper level ridge of high pressure moved over the region and persisted through the end of July and the first of August. Across the region, multiple areas in the lower elevations reached critical thresholds for heat risk, while many mountain zones saw consecutive days with high temperatures exceeding 95 degrees Fahrenheit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple RAWS stations across the zone recorded consecutive maximum daily high temperatures of 95 degrees or greater from July 26th through the 31st.

CZ_NAME: EAST SLOPES OF THE OREGON CASCADES
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A potent upper level ridge of high pressure moved over the region and persisted through the end of July and the first of August. Across the region, multiple areas in the lower elevations reached critical thresholds for heat risk, while many mountain zones saw consecutive days with high temperatures exceeding 95 degrees Fahrenheit.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple RAWS stations across the zone recorded consecutive maximum daily high temperatures of 95 degrees or greater temperatures from July 25th through the 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A hot and humid airmass send heat indices soaring from 95 to 102 degrees across much of west and central Upper Michigan on the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices peaked at 102 degrees near Peavy Falls Dam during the early afternoon of the 18th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices across Marquette County peaked between 95 and 100 degrees during the early to mid-afternoon hours of the 18th.
