A very strong ridge of high pressure settled over the Colombia River basin bringing hot daytime temperatures and warm overnight lows. The consecutive days of heat made it difficult to cool locations without air conditioning. Daily record highs were set for at least one observation site.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Highs temperatures reached from 100 to 108 degrees Fahrenheit with overnight lows in the upper 60s to lower 70s. Pierce ID set record high temperatures on July 29 and August 1, and also remained above 95F for 6 straight days from July 29 to August 3.  This was its 2nd longest such streak.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An exceptionally hot summer really got going during the early to middle part of July as triple digit heat became the norm. Most of the region reached Heat Advisory criteria, and a good portion of the area met or exceeded Excessive Heat criteria at some point during this July stretch of hot weather.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The summer heat increased to Excessive Heat criteria with ambient temperatures near or above 105 degrees and/or heat index values near or above 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A very strong ridge of high pressure settled over the Northern Rockies. Daily record highs were set for multiple observation sites.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: With high temperatures ranging from 95 to 104F over 5 days, this was the hottest period of the summer. Missoula set record high temperatures 4 straight days from July 29 through Aug 1, and remained 100F or warmer for high temperatures for 5 consecutive days.  This tied the longest streak of 100F days ever.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An expansive ridge of high pressure aloft forced a strong warm plume to the northeast, ahead of a frontal boundary on August 5.  The combination of temperatures in the mid to upper 90s and dew point readings in the mid 60s to around 70 led to heat index values from 105-110 for several hours across south central and southeast South Dakota.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in the upper 90s and dew point readings in the upper 60s resulted in heat index values as high as 105 degrees 10 miles west of Geddes, 109 degrees at Wagner, and 111 degrees at Platte.

A persistent upper level ridge spanning much of the Southern U.S. in mid July maintained hot temperatures across all of the Four State Region from July 16th through the 18th, with daytime temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower and middle 100s. When combined with the daytime humidity, oppressively hot conditions were observed as heat indices averaged between 105-109 degrees during the peak heating hours. Unfortunately, a heat-related fatality occurred in Natchitoches Parish on July 17th when a 52 year old male police officer suffered a heat stroke while patrolling the streets of Downtown Natchitoches during the late afternoon hours.

An expansive upper level ridge centered over the Southern Plains eastward into the lower Mississippi Valley in late July led to consecutive days of abnormally hot temperatures across all of the Four State Region, with daytime temperatures climbing into the upper 90s to lower 100s each afternoon. Wet soils from widespread rains that occurred during the 21st-22nd also did not allow for much mixing of dew points, with oppressively hot conditions observed as heat indices ranged from 105-109 degrees each day during the peak heating hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices met or exceeded 105 on most afternoons from July 6 through July 31 across Dallas County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another round of Excessive Heat plagued the region with ambient temperatures near or above 105 degrees and/or heat index values near or above 110 degrees.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Another round of Excessive Heat plagued the region in July with ambient temperatures near or above 105 degrees and/or heat index values near or above 110 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An expansive ridge of high pressure aloft forced a strong warm plume to the northeast, ahead of a frontal boundary on August 5.  The combination of temperatures in the mid to upper 90s and dew point readings in the mid 60s to around 70 led to heat index values from 105-110 for several hours across south central and southeast South Dakota.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in the upper 90s and dew point readings in the mid to upper 60s resulted in heat index values as high as 108 degrees 6 miles south-southwest of Utica.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure that was centered over the Great Basin area built westward into California on August 31st and brought a period of hot and dry weather to the area which prevailed across the area through much of early September. An Excessive Heat Warning was issued for a large portion of the area including all of the San Joaquin Valley, the West Side Hills, the Sierra Foothills, Yosemite Valley, The Kern River Valley and the Kern County desert areas and remained in effect until the evening hours of September 9.  The large high pressure area finally broke down on September 9 and temperatures remained below dangerous levels on September 10.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 103 and 108 degrees on September 1, 3 and 4, between 105 and 110 degrees on September 2, 5, 8 and 9 and between 110 and 115 degrees on September 6 and 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure built in across the Southwest heading into the middle part of June, bringing excessive heat conditions to the region. High temperatures in Phoenix officially approached or exceeded 110 degrees between June 8-12th, which is well above the seasonal normal. The hottest temperature during this timeframe occurred on the 11th when the high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked at 114 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 36 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over interior northern California brought widespread high to very high heat risk to the region. Triple-digit high temperatures were observed across most of the Central Valley, Delta, and foothills through the first 9 days of September. The hottest temperatures were on September 5 and 6, when temperatures exceeding 110 were observed at many locations. All-time records were set on the 6th for Sacramento stations and tied in Stockton. Numerous daily and monthly record high-temperature were also set in the area. There was one death attributed to the heat in Sacramento County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake Shasta Dam saw high temperatures reach 100 to 111 degrees during the event. The hottest days were on the 6th when the high was 110 and 111 on the 7th; these were both daily records. Morning lows were also high, dropping only to 78 on the 8th and 80 on the 9th. The minimum of 80 was the highest ever in September, breaking the record of 79 set on the 10th in 2011.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Four ASOS sites recorded their hottest September temperatures ever.   They were Pocatello, Idaho Falls, Burley, and Challis.  For the entire month the number of record high temperatures recorded were:  Pocatello 5, Idaho Falls 6, Burley 3, Challis 5, and Stanley 2.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Pocatello ASOS at the airport recorded the hottest September temperatures ever recorded with 102 degrees on the 3rd.   Two other days reached 100 degrees and 5 record highs were recorded during the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge brought record heat area wide in late September.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 82 was set at Seattle-Tacoma WA airport on September 26th. This breaks the old record of 78 set in 1970.||A record high temperature of 80 was set at Seattle WA WFO on September 26th. This breaks the old record of 79 set in 1949.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over interior northern California brought widespread high to very high heat risk to the region. Triple-digit high temperatures were observed across most of the Central Valley, Delta, and foothills through the first 9 days of September. The hottest temperatures were on September 5 and 6, when temperatures exceeding 110 were observed at many locations. All-time records were set on the 6th for Sacramento stations and tied in Stockton. Numerous daily and monthly record high-temperature were also set in the area. There was one death attributed to the heat in Sacramento County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Southern Sacramento Valley region saw all-time, monthly and daily record highs set, reaching up to 116 degrees during the event. On the 6th Downtown Sacramento recorded a high temperature of 116, which broke the all-time record high of 114 degrees set on July 17, 1925. This also broke the September record of 113 which was set the day before on the 5th. The previous monthly record of 109 was set on September 1, 1950, and tied on September 2, 1955 and September 6, 2020. The record of consecutive days over 110 was tied at 2. Daily highs were also set with 113 on the 5th and 8th and 109 on the 7th. The low of 80 on the 7th was the warmest on record in September and in all months was surpassed only on July 23, 2006, which had a low of 84. Sacramento International Airport set an all-time daily record high of 116 on the 5th and 6th, and also set a record of 4 consecutive days of 110 or higher. Sacramento Executive Airport set an all-time daily record high of 114 on the 5th and 6th. The Sacramento County Coroner attributed the death of one unhoused 49 year old man to the heat, having died while in a hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over interior northern California brought widespread high to very high heat risk to the region. Triple-digit high temperatures were observed across most of the Central Valley, Delta, and foothills through the first 9 days of September. Numerous daily and monthly record high-temperature were also set in the area. There was one death attributed to the heat in Sacramento County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Delta regions saw high temperatures reach up to 116 degrees. Fairfield/Travis AFB reached 116 on the 5th and 6th, while the COOP station in Fairfield recorded 114 on each date. Highs remained above 100 from the 1st to the 10th. The highest low was 75 on the 7th at Fairfield COOP, and 76 at Fairfield/Travis AFB on the 6th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over interior northern California brought widespread high to very high heat risk to the region. Triple-digit high temperatures were observed across most of the Central Valley, Delta, and foothills through the first 9 days of September. The hottest temperatures were on September 5 and 6, when temperatures exceeding 110 were observed at many locations. All-time records were set on the 6th for Sacramento stations and tied in Stockton. Numerous daily and monthly record high-temperature were also set in the area. There was one death attributed to the heat in Sacramento County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Northern San Joaquin Valley saw high temperatures reach 102 to 115 degrees during the heat event, with all-time, monthly, and daily record highs set. The all-time record high of 115 for Stockton Airport was tied on the 6th, previously set on July 23, 2006. The monthly record high was broken, which was 114 on July 14, 1972. Daily records were also set on the 5th and 8th with highs of 112 and tied on the 4th with a high of 105, and 106 on the 9th. Stockton saw a mild low of only 79 on the 8th. Modesto Airport had a September record high of 112 set on the 6th, with daily record highs of 107 set on the 5th and 108 on the 8th, with a record-tying high of 107 on the 7th. Modesto saw a mild low of only 79 on the 8th.

The hottest days were the 5th and 6th. Cohasset had a high of 110 with a low of 86 on the 5th, a high of 112, and a low of 90 on the 6th.  Jarbo Gap had a high of 106 and a low of 77 on the 5th and a high of 109 and a low of 81 on the 6th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over interior northern California brought widespread high to very high heat risk to the region. Triple-digit high temperatures were observed across most of the Central Valley, Delta, and foothills through the first 9 days of September. The hottest temperatures were on September 5 and 6, when temperatures exceeding 110 were observed at many locations. All-time records were set on the 6th for Sacramento stations and tied in Stockton. Numerous daily and monthly record high-temperature were also set in the area. There was one death attributed to the heat in Sacramento County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Motherlode region saw high temperatures reach upwards of 109 to 115 degrees during the heat event, with lows in the upper 70s to mid-80s. The hottest days were the 5th and 6th: Auburn Airport high of 109 and a low of 77, then a high of 111 and a low of 82, Placerville Airport high of 104 and a low of 82, then a high of 108 and a low of 82, Reader Ranch high 113 and a low of 74 then a high 115 and a low of 76, and Nevada County Air Park in Grass Valley a high 104 and a low of 81 and then a high 108 and a low of 81.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An expansive ridge of high pressure aloft forced a strong warm plume to the northeast, ahead of a frontal boundary on August 5.  The combination of temperatures in the mid to upper 90s and dew point readings in the mid 60s to around 70 led to heat index values from 105-110 for several hours across south central and southeast South Dakota.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in the upper 90s and dew point readings in the mid to upper 60s resulted in heat index values as high as 106 degrees at Scotland.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure that was centered over the Great Basin area built westward into California on August 31st and brought a period of hot and dry weather to the area which prevailed across the area through much of early September. An Excessive Heat Warning was issued for a large portion of the area including all of the San Joaquin Valley, the West Side Hills, the Sierra Foothills, Yosemite Valley, The Kern River Valley and the Kern County desert areas and remained in effect until the evening hours of September 9.  The large high pressure area finally broke down on September 9 and temperatures remained below dangerous levels on September 10.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 108 and 113 degrees each day between September 1 and September 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over interior northern California brought widespread high to very high heat risk to the region. Triple-digit high temperatures were observed across most of the Central Valley, Delta, and foothills through the first 9 days of September. The hottest temperatures were on September 5 and 6, when temperatures exceeding 110 were observed at many locations. All-time records were set on the 6th for Sacramento stations and tied in Stockton. Numerous daily and monthly record high-temperature were also set in the area. There was one death attributed to the heat in Sacramento County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of Western Plumas County and Lassen National Park saw high temperatures reach up to 97 to 108 degrees during the heat event, with ranging from the mid-60s to around 80.  The hottest days were the 5th and 6th: Quincy Road had highs of 107 and 108, Chester 101 each day, Lassen Lodge 105 and 104, and Cashman 103 each day.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over interior northern California brought widespread high to very high heat risk to the region. Triple-digit high temperatures were observed across most of the Central Valley, Delta, and foothills through the first 9 days of September. The hottest temperatures were on September 5 and 6, when temperatures exceeding 110 were observed at many locations. All-time records were set on the 6th for Sacramento stations and tied in Stockton. Numerous daily and monthly record high-temperature were also set in the area. There was one death attributed to the heat in Sacramento County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Portions of the West Slope of the Northern Sierra saw high temperatures reach up to 95 to 107, with lows in the 70s to around 80.  The hottest days were the 5th and 6th. Blue Canyon had a high of 95 with a low of 78 on the 5th, a high of 96, and a low of 78 on the 6th. The previous monthly record high was 93 set on September 5, 2020, and the previous monthly record maximum low was 77 set on September 6, 2020. Other notable area high temperatures on the 5th and 6th: 103 and 105 at Bald Mountain, 105 and 107 at Beaver, 103 and 104 at White Cloud, and 103 and 105 at Elizabeth. Even Duncan RAWS at an elevation of 7,182 feet reached 90 and 89.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure built in across the Southwest heading into the middle part of June, bringing excessive heat conditions to the region. High temperatures in Phoenix officially approached or exceeded 110 degrees between June 8-12th, which is well above the seasonal normal. The hottest temperature during this timeframe occurred on the 11th when the high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked at 114 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 36 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent and amplified ridge brought a prolonged period of unusually hot temperatures to western and central Wyoming for the beginning of September 2022. Most lower elevation sites saw high temperatures topping 90 F for several days, including a few locations reaching 100 F. All time September high temperatures were set at several sites including: Riverton, Lander, Casper, Worland, Buffalo, Greybull, Big Piney and Lake Yellowstone. Temperatures cooled on September 8th and 9th when a strong cold front moved southward across the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS weather station at the Riverton Airport (Central Wyoming Airport) observed record high temperatures on 6 consecutive days. Highs were 90 or greater on the first 8 days of the month. The high temperature of 100 F on September 4th is the all time high for September, as well as the latest date to reach 100 F on record.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent and amplified ridge brought a prolonged period of unusually hot temperatures to western and central Wyoming for the beginning of September 2022. Most lower elevation sites saw high temperatures topping 90 F for several days, including a few locations reaching 100 F. All time September high temperatures were set at several sites including: Riverton, Lander, Casper, Worland, Buffalo, Greybull, Big Piney and Lake Yellowstone. Temperatures cooled on September 8th and 9th when a strong cold front moved southward across the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at the Lander Airport (Hunt Field Airport) recorded 6 consecutive days of record high temperatures over 90 degrees F. The high temperature of 99 F on September 4th is the all time record high for the month of September. Records at Lander date back to 1891.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent and amplified ridge brought a prolonged period of unusually hot temperatures to western and central Wyoming for the beginning of September 2022. Most lower elevation sites saw high temperatures topping 90 F for several days, including a few locations reaching 100 F. All time September high temperatures were set at several sites including: Riverton, Lander, Casper, Worland, Buffalo, Greybull, Big Piney and Lake Yellowstone. Temperatures cooled on September 8th and 9th when a strong cold front moved southward across the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Rock Springs Airport (Southwest Wyoming Regional Airport) had 6 consecutive days of record high temperatures in the 90s. The high temperatures of 93 F on the 4th and 7th are now tied for the all time high temperature for the month of September.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong high pressure over interior northern California brought widespread high to very high heat risk to the region. Triple-digit high temperatures were observed across most of the Central Valley, Delta, and foothills through the first 9 days of September. The hottest temperatures were on September 5 and 6, when temperatures exceeding 110 were observed at many locations. All-time records were set on the 6th for Sacramento stations and tied in Stockton. Numerous daily and monthly record high-temperature were also set in the area. There was one death attributed to the heat in Sacramento County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Northern Sacramento Valley saw daily records broken, with high temperatures reaching 110 to 115 degrees, and with low temperatures reaching up to 90. Redding Airport reached 115 degrees on the 6th (old record 111 in 2020), with Red Bluff peaking at 114 (old record 113 in 2020). On the 8th Redding Airport reached 112 degrees (old record 109 in 1923), with Red Bluff peaking at 113 (old record 112 in 1944). On the 9th Redding Airport reached 112 degrees (old record 110 in 1944), with Red Bluff peaking at 112 (tying the old record of 112 in 1944). On the 9th Redding recorded a daily record high minimum temperature of 87 degrees and Red Bluff 82 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An expansive ridge of high pressure aloft forced a strong warm plume to the northeast, ahead of a frontal boundary on August 5.  The combination of temperatures in the mid to upper 90s and dew point readings in the mid 60s to around 70 led to heat index values from 105-110 for several hours across south central and southeast South Dakota.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures in the mid to upper 90s and dew point readings in the upper 60s to around 70 resulted in heat index values as high as 106 degrees near Kimball.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent and amplified ridge brought a prolonged period of unusually hot temperatures to western and central Wyoming for the beginning of September 2022. Most lower elevation sites saw high temperatures topping 90 F for several days, including a few locations reaching 100 F. All time September high temperatures were set at several sites including: Riverton, Lander, Casper, Worland, Buffalo, Greybull, Big Piney and Lake Yellowstone. Temperatures cooled on September 8th and 9th when a strong cold front moved southward across the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Casper Airport (CasperNatrona County International Airport) had 7 consecutive days of high temperatures 90 F or greater. In addition, the high temperature of 100 F on September 4th is the all time high temperature for the month of September, and the first ever recorded 100 degree temperature in the month. Records at the site date back to 1947.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent and amplified ridge brought a prolonged period of unusually hot temperatures to western and central Wyoming for the beginning of September 2022. Most lower elevation sites saw high temperatures topping 90 F for several days, including a few locations reaching 100 F. All time September high temperatures were set at several sites including: Riverton, Lander, Casper, Worland, Buffalo, Greybull, Big Piney and Lake Yellowstone. Temperatures cooled on September 8th and 9th when a strong cold front moved southward across the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record and near record temperatures were observed at the Johnson County Airport (near Buffalo, WY)  for the first 7 days of the month. The heat peaked on September 4th with a high temperature of 100 F. This is the all time high temperature for September, and the first ever recorded 100 degree F temperature for the month of September.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent and amplified ridge brought a prolonged period of unusually hot temperatures to western and central Wyoming for the beginning of September 2022. Most lower elevation sites saw high temperatures topping 90 F for several days, including a few locations reaching 100 F. All time September high temperatures were set at several sites including: Riverton, Lander, Casper, Worland, Buffalo, Greybull, Big Piney and Lake Yellowstone. Temperatures cooled on September 8th and 9th when a strong cold front moved southward across the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The month started with 7 consecutive days of high temperatures over 90 degrees at the Worland Municipal Airport. Most notable was the high of 102 F on September 4th, which broke the all time September high temperature.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This is the second of three entries documenting the long-duration excessive heat episode which lasted from August 30th through September 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: This event began in August. Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached on each of the first four days of September, and the event continued beyond.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early September heat starting in August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at San Diego International Airport observed daily highs reaching at least the middle to upper 80s through much of early September, with several days reaching the lower to middle 90s. The highest daily maximum temperature of 95 degrees occurred on the afternoon of Saturday September 3rd, with a high of 94 occurring on Thursday, September 8th. Highs on Saturday, September 10th were significantly cooler due to clouds and rain associated with the approach of Hurricane Kay, which ended the heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early September heat starting in August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at John Wayne International Airport observed daily highs reaching at least the lower to middle 90s through much of early September, with several days ranging from 97 to 106 degrees. The highest daily maximum temperature of 106 degrees occurred on the afternoon of Sunday September 4th, with a high of 102 occurring on Thursday, September 8th. Highs on Saturday, September 10th were significantly cooler due to clouds and rain associated with the approach of Hurricane Kay, which ended the heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early September heat starting in August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The ASOS at Ramona Airport observed daily highs ranging from 100 to 107 degrees through much of early September. The highest daily maximum temperature of 107 degrees occurred on the afternoon of Wednesday September 7th, with a high of 104 degrees occurring on all of the September 1st, 4th, and 6th. Highs on Saturday, September 10th were significantly cooler due to clouds and rain associated with the approach of Hurricane Kay, which ended the heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent and amplified ridge brought a prolonged period of unusually hot temperatures to western and central Wyoming for the beginning of September 2022. Most lower elevation sites saw high temperatures topping 90 F for several days, including a few locations reaching 100 F. All time September high temperatures were set at several sites including: Riverton, Lander, Casper, Worland, Buffalo, Greybull, Big Piney and Lake Yellowstone. Temperatures cooled on September 8th and 9th when a strong cold front moved southward across the state.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At the Greybull Airport (South Big Horn County Airport) there were 7 consecutive days of high temperatures over 90 degrees to start the month. On the 4th and 7th, the all time September high temperature of 103 degrees F was set then tied. The 103 F on September 7th is now the latest 100 F or greater temperature for the site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent and amplified ridge brought a prolonged period of unusually hot temperatures to western and central Wyoming for the beginning of September 2022. Most lower elevation sites saw high temperatures topping 90 F for several days, including a few locations reaching 100 F. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record heat occurred at the Lake Yellowstone ASOS. Five consecutive days had high temperatures of 80 F or greater. On September 7th, a record high temperature of 83 degrees F broke the all time record high for September.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A persistent and amplified ridge brought a prolonged period of unusually hot temperatures to western and central Wyoming for the beginning of September 2022. Most lower elevation sites saw high temperatures topping 90 F for several days, including a few locations reaching 100 F. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Record and near record temperatures occurred at the Big Piney-Marbleton Airport. On September 4th, 6th, and 7th, record high temperatures of 91 F set and then tied (twice) the all time high temperature for the month of September. September 7th is also the latest 90 degree F or greater temperature for this site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomalously high upper level ridge stayed over the region for several days in early September. This led to 2 consecutive days of record high temperatures in the region, with many stations recording triple digit temperatures. There was one recorded fatality from this extreme heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple newspapers reported on an infant that died after being left in a hot car in New Plymouth, Idaho on September 6th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large upper level ridge over the Intermountain West resulted in a multiday heat wave from September 6th through the 8th. Multiple high temperature records were broken including the September monthly record at Cheyenne on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Cheyenne Airport ASOS station (KCYS) recorded an afternoon high of 97 degrees Fahrenheit. This broke the September monthly record high with temperatures in the upper 90s for a second day in a row.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure that was centered over the Great Basin area built westward into California on August 31st and brought a period of hot and dry weather to the area which prevailed across the area through much of early September. An Excessive Heat Warning was issued for a large portion of the area including all of the San Joaquin Valley, the West Side Hills, the Sierra Foothills, Yosemite Valley, The Kern River Valley and the Kern County desert areas and remained in effect until the evening hours of September 9.  The large high pressure area finally broke down on September 9 and temperatures remained below dangerous levels on September 10.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs generally ranged between 103 and 108 degrees on September 1, 3 and 4, between 105 and 110 degrees on September 2, 5, 8 and 9 and between 110 and 115 degrees on September 6 and 7.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Seven people died in the Las Vegas area of heat-related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven people died in the Las Vegas area of heat-related causes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Early September heat starting in August.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Beaumont AWOS site observed daily highs ranging from the upper 90s to upwards of 105 degrees through much of early September. The highest daily maximum temperature of 105 degrees occurred on both the afternoons of Thursday, September 1st and Tuesday September 6th, with a high of 102 degrees occurring on both the 4th and 5th of September. Highs on Friday, September 9th were significantly cooler due to clouds and rain associated with the approach of Hurricane Kay, which ended the heat wave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A high school cross country meet was held near Stewartville (Olmsted County) on September 1st. Fourteen runners needed treatment for heat exhaustion with four of them transported to a hospital for additional aid. Observations from the automated weather observing equipment at the Rochester (Olmsted County) airport indicated that conditions were unusually humid for early September with dew points in the lower 70s.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fourteen participants from a cross country meet near Stewartville were treated for heat exhaustion with four transported to a hospital. Observations from the automated weather observing equipment at the Rochester airport indicated it was unusually humid with dew points in the lower 70s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid weather ahead of an approaching cold front led to heat indices reaching between 95F and 100F degrees as well as a few severe thunderstorms across eastern New York on August 30, 2022. Heat indices in excess of 95F degrees were concentrated along the Hudson River Valley. Severe thunderstorms were focused across the Upper Hudson Valley as well as southern Herkimer County. Damage was mainly due to downed trees and wires, though lightning strikes caused two separate house fires. Heavy rainfall also led to some minor street flooding around Glens Falls. A few power outages occurred across the Upper Hudson Valley as a result of the storms.

A dome of high pressure brought a stretch of hot and humid weather resulting in multiple days of heat indices between 95F and 104F degrees across eastern New York between August 4-9, 2022. ||On August 4, record high temperatures were set at both Albany and Poughkeepsie, each reaching 99F degrees. Albany and Poughkeepsie also set a new record for the hottest 8-day start to August on record.||The stretch of hot weather led to the opening of multiple cooling centers across the region.

During the latter part of June, the Southwest was under the influence of a strong ridge of high pressure centered over the southern Plains. This allowed temperatures to climb slightly above seasonal normal values between the 21st through the 26th. At Phoenix Sky Harbor, afternoon high temperatures topped out at 108 degrees for several days during this time. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 13 heat-associated fatalities occurred due to this heat event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the end of June, a strong ridge of high pressure set up across the western United States, becoming centered over the Great Basin. This led to temperatures climbing slightly above normal across the Phoenix area, with the afternoon high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaking at 109 degrees on the 29th. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 10 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

Albany and Poughkeepsie also set a new record for the hottest 8-day start to August on record.||The stretch of hot weather led to the opening of multiple cooling centers across the region.

Hot and humid conditions during the early to mid afternoon on June 24, 2022 resulted in peak heat indices of 113 to 117 across Lake, Volusia, Orange, Seminole, Osceola, Okeechobee, and Brevard Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Florida FAWN station at Okahumpka, KHPF1, measured a peak heat index of 114F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions during the early to mid afternoon on June 24, 2022 resulted in peak heat indices of 113 to 117 across Lake, Volusia, Orange, Seminole, Osceola, Okeechobee, and Brevard Counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The RAWS stations at Lake George, LGRF1, and Lake Woodruff, LWQF1, both measured a peak heat index of 115F. The Florida FAWN at Pierson, EPRF1, measured a peak heat index value of 122F. This occurred because west winds brought very moist air off of Lake George causing dew points at the Pierson FAWN to reach up to 83F.

A strong ridge of high pressure built in across the Southwest heading into the middle part of June, bringing excessive heat conditions to the region. High temperatures in Phoenix officially approached or exceeded 110 degrees between June 8-12th, which is well above the seasonal normal. The hottest temperature during this timeframe occurred on the 11th when the high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked at 114 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 36 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure was centered over the Central Plains during the middle part of the month with the Desert Southwest feeling its influence. This brought excessive heat conditions to the region with temperatures in Phoenix peaking at 113 on the 16th. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 9 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

A dome of high pressure brought a stretch of hot and humid weather resulting in multiple days of heat indices between 95F and 104F degrees across eastern New York between August 4-9, 2022. ||On August 4, record high temperatures were set at both Albany and Poughkeepsie, each reaching 99F degrees. Albany and Poughkeepsie also set a new record for the hottest 8-day start to August on record.||The stretch of hot weather led to the opening of multiple cooling centers across the region.

During the latter part of June, the Southwest was under the influence of a strong ridge of high pressure centered over the southern Plains. This allowed temperatures to climb slightly above seasonal normal values between the 21st through the 26th. At Phoenix Sky Harbor, afternoon high temperatures topped out at 108 degrees for several days during this time. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 13 heat-associated fatalities occurred due to this heat event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four fatalities (2 direct and 2 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

Hot and humid weather ahead of an approaching cold front led to heat indices reaching between 95F and 100F degrees as well as a few severe thunderstorms across eastern New York on August 30, 2022. Heat indices in excess of 95F degrees were concentrated along the Hudson River Valley. Severe thunderstorms were focused across the Upper Hudson Valley as well as southern Herkimer County. Damage was mainly due to downed trees and wires, though lightning strikes caused two separate house fires. Heavy rainfall also led to some minor street flooding around Glens Falls. A few power outages occurred across the Upper Hudson Valley as a result of the storms.
Upper-level high pressure continued over the region. Hot and humid conditions prevailed for much of the month.

CZ_NAME: MOUNTAINS OF SAN BENITO COUNTY AND INTERIOR MONTEREY COUNTY INCLUDING PINNACLES NATIONAL PARK
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure encompassed the Western CONUS from September 1st through 8th, leading to anomalously hot temperatures along the California coast, and even more extreme temperatures in interior valleys and all mountain zones, where very hot daytime temperatures combined with a lack of overnight cooling created extreme heat risk . Excessive Heat Warnings were issued for interior areas and mountains of Monterey/San Benito Counties for the period September 1st through 8th, and for interior valleys and mountain zones around the San Francisco Bay Area from September 4th through 8th. A combination of Heat Advisories and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for parts of Monterey Bay and its near coastal valleys, the San Francisco Bay Shoreline, and Marin Coastal Mountains from September 4th through 8th, along with a Heat Advisory for the Central Coast, San Francisco, and coastal North Bay on September 6th. Several daily record high temperature records were shattered, along with a handful of monthly and all-time records. Triple digit temperatures were reported across a vast swath of the interior, with some sites reaching 110 degrees and higher. Reports of power outages, heat related illnesses and deaths were received. Counties opened/operated one or more cooling centers to provide relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pinnacles NP reported a max temperature of 111 degrees. Several other unofficial sites in the surrounding mountains reported high temperatures between 102 and 108 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The summer heat started a little early with Heat Advisories and Excessive Heat Warnings during the June 11-13th period. Maximum heat indices exceeded 105 across just about all of North and Central Texas. Ambient temperatures actually exceeded 105 for many counties, particularly along and west of the I-35 corridor on June 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees during the afternoon hours of June 11th-13th. The County was also under an Excessive Heat Warning on June 12th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged heat wave gripped most of southern Illinois for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 105 to 120 degrees. The exception was the Interstate 64 corridor from Mount Vernon to Mount Carmel, where the dangerous levels of heat lasted only from the 4th until the 6th. The hottest day in southern Illinois was the 5th, when the heat index peaked between 111 and 120 at all airport sites. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared into the mid and upper 90's. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Carbondale set a daily record warm low temperature of 79 degrees on the 6th.

Another episode of hazardous heat impacted far western Kentucky, mainly west of Kentucky Lake. Peak heat indices on the afternoons of the 26th and 27th were around 105 degrees. Hot and humid southwest winds persisted ahead of a cold front as it moved east from the Plains toward the Mississippi Valley. Actual high temperatures were in the lower 90's.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strengthening upper level ridge spanning much of the Southern U.S. in mid July led to excessively hot temperatures across all of the Four State Region on July 21st. However, a weak surface front backdoored southwest through Southwest Arkansas during the afternoon, resulting in compressional warming ahead of it over portions of North-central Louisiana. This allowed for afternoon temperatures to climb to near 100 degrees over this area, with moisture pooling ahead of the front resulting in heat indices ranging from 110-112 degrees during the peak heating hours.
Hot temperatures and high humidity continued into the second week of July with a more widespread heat episode occurring on the 10th and 11th across south Texas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ambient temperatures at or above 103 along with heat indices at or above 105 were felt across most of North and Central Texas Thursday June 23 through Saturday June 25.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A maximum heat index of 105 was reached the afternoon of June 24 at Denton Enterprise Airport. Denton Public Health reported 1 case of heat exhaustion and 1 case of heat stroke during this period.

CZ_NAME: MOUNTAINS OF SAN BENITO COUNTY AND INTERIOR MONTEREY COUNTY INCLUDING PINNACLES NATIONAL PARK
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 590 DAM ridge at 500 mb built over CA Thursday June 9 into Friday June 10, leading to rapid warming of the airmass and daytime surface temperatures reaching into the 90s to over 100 degrees over a large swath of the state away from the coast. A heat advisory was issued covering interior portions (mountains and valleys) of the SF Bay Area and Central Coast for June 10 from 11 AM until 10 PM.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Pinnacles NP reached a high of 103 degrees. Fort Hunter Liggett reached 105 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged heat wave gripped most of southern Illinois for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 105 to 120 degrees. The exception was the Interstate 64 corridor from Mount Vernon to Mount Carmel, where the dangerous levels of heat lasted only from the 4th until the 6th. The hottest day in southern Illinois was the 5th, when the heat index peaked between 111 and 120 at all airport sites. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Heat indices topped 110 degrees across most of southern Illinois in the afternoon. Peak heat indices ranged from 110 at Metropolis to 114 at Carbondale and 116 at Carmi. Along the Interstate 64 corridor, heat indices were a bit lower. Mount Vernon peaked at 109 degrees. A hot and humid southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front brought temperatures up to the mid 90's. Dew points were exceptionally high, with readings in the lower 80's at most stations.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the southern United States during mid July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching 100 to 110 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of west central Arkansas on the 19th through 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ambient temperatures at or above 103 along with heat indices at or above 105 were felt across most of North and Central Texas Thursday June 23 through Saturday June 25.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A high temperature of 104 was reached on June 24 and 103 on June 25 in Granbury, TX.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The summer heat started a little early with Heat Advisories and Excessive Heat Warnings during the June 11-13th period. Maximum heat indices exceeded 105 across just about all of North and Central Texas. Ambient temperatures actually exceeded 105 for many counties, particularly along and west of the I-35 corridor on June 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees during the afternoon hours of June 11th-13th. The County was also under an Excessive Heat Warning on June 12th but did not technically reach criteria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the end of June, a strong ridge of high pressure set up across the western United States, becoming centered over the Great Basin. This led to temperatures climbing slightly above normal across the Phoenix area, with the afternoon high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaking at 109 degrees on the 29th. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 10 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure built in across the Southwest heading into the middle part of June, bringing excessive heat conditions to the region. High temperatures in Phoenix officially approached or exceeded 110 degrees between June 8-12th, which is well above the seasonal normal. The hottest temperature during this timeframe occurred on the 11th when the high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked at 114 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 36 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.

Heat indices topped 110 degrees across most of southern Illinois in the afternoon. Peak heat indices ranged from 110 at Metropolis to 114 at Carbondale and 116 at Carmi. Along the Interstate 64 corridor, heat indices were a bit lower. Mount Vernon peaked at 109 degrees. A hot and humid southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front brought temperatures up to the mid 90's. Dew points were exceptionally high, with readings in the lower 80's at most stations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 590 DAM ridge at 500 mb built over CA Thursday June 9 into Friday June 10, leading to rapid warming of the airmass and daytime surface temperatures reaching into the 90s to over 100 degrees over a large swath of the state away from the coast. A heat advisory was issued covering interior portions (mountains and valleys) of the SF Bay Area and Central Coast for June 10 from 11 AM until 10 PM.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Concord and Livermore airports reached a high of 100 degrees on June 10. The minimum temperature on June 11 was 70 degrees at Concord.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure developed over the area along with light offshore flow, allowing temperatures to soar into the 90s to low 100s for all areas, except parts of the immediate coastline. A head advisory was issued for all but coastal zones from late morning through the evening of June 21.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downtown Oakland reached a high temperature of 98 degrees, tying its daily record from 1981.

CZ_NAME: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure developed over the area along with light offshore flow, allowing temperatures to soar into the 90s to low 100s for all areas, except parts of the immediate coastline. A head advisory was issued for all but coastal zones from late morning through the evening of June 21.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: San Jose airport reached a high of 102 degrees, breaking its daily record of 101 deg from 1973.

CZ_NAME: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure encompassed the Western CONUS from September 1st through 8th, leading to anomalously hot temperatures along the California coast, and even more extreme temperatures in interior valleys and all mountain zones, where very hot daytime temperatures combined with a lack of overnight cooling created extreme heat risk . Excessive Heat Warnings were issued for interior areas and mountains of Monterey/San Benito Counties for the period September 1st through 8th, and for interior valleys and mountain zones around the San Francisco Bay Area from September 4th through 8th. A combination of Heat Advisories and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for parts of Monterey Bay and its near coastal valleys, the San Francisco Bay Shoreline, and Marin Coastal Mountains from September 4th through 8th, along with a Heat Advisory for the Central Coast, San Francisco, and coastal North Bay on September 6th. Several daily record high temperature records were shattered, along with a handful of monthly and all-time records. Triple digit temperatures were reported across a vast swath of the interior, with some sites reaching 110 degrees and higher. Reports of power outages, heat related illnesses and deaths were received. Counties opened/operated one or more cooling centers to provide relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public libraries were used as cooling shelters throughout the county. Cost of operating libraries beyond normal business hours was $1732.04.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere restrengthened over the southern United States during late July. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching 100 to 110 degrees, combined with high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of west central Arkansas on the 25th through 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the south central United States during mid June. High pressure building over the Desert Southwest brought widespread excessive heat conditions. The episode continued into September.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached two days in a row.

Temperatures across South Florida were in the lower 90s with relative humidity values over 50%. This led to high heat index values and contributed to the death of a child who was left in a car during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 3-year-old boy died after being left in a closed vehicle at a school in North Miami-Dade County. Afternoon temperatures reached the lower 90s and heat index values were in the lower 100s, which are a few degrees above normal.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ambient temperatures at or above 103 along with heat indices at or above 105 were felt across most of North and Central Texas Thursday June 23 through Saturday June 25.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values climbed to near 110 the afternoons of June 23 and 24th, then to 106 the afternoon of June 25th, in the city of Plano, TX.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure encompassed the Western CONUS from September 1st through 8th, leading to anomalously hot temperatures along the California coast, and even more extreme temperatures in interior valleys and all mountain zones, where very hot daytime temperatures combined with a lack of overnight cooling created extreme heat risk . Excessive Heat Warnings were issued for interior areas and mountains of Monterey/San Benito Counties for the period September 1st through 8th, and for interior valleys and mountain zones around the San Francisco Bay Area from September 4th through 8th. A combination of Heat Advisories and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for parts of Monterey Bay and its near coastal valleys, the San Francisco Bay Shoreline, and Marin Coastal Mountains from September 4th through 8th, along with a Heat Advisory for the Central Coast, San Francisco, and coastal North Bay on September 6th. Several daily record high temperature records were shattered, along with a handful of monthly and all-time records. Triple digit temperatures were reported across a vast swath of the interior, with some sites reaching 110 degrees and higher. Reports of power outages, heat related illnesses and deaths were received. Counties opened/operated one or more cooling centers to provide relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: SFO ASOS set a new daily max temperature record of 97 deg., breaking the previous record of 93 deg., set in 2004. Downtown Oakland Coop site set a new daily max temperature record of 100 deg., breaking the previous record of 95 deg. set in 2008. Redwood City Coop site set a new daily max temperature record of 107 deg., breaking the previous record of 97 deg., set in 1983.

CZ_NAME: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure encompassed the Western CONUS from September 1st through 8th, leading to anomalously hot temperatures along the California coast, and even more extreme temperatures in interior valleys and all mountain zones, where very hot daytime temperatures combined with a lack of overnight cooling created extreme heat risk . Excessive Heat Warnings were issued for interior areas and mountains of Monterey/San Benito Counties for the period September 1st through 8th, and for interior valleys and mountain zones around the San Francisco Bay Area from September 4th through 8th. A combination of Heat Advisories and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for parts of Monterey Bay and its near coastal valleys, the San Francisco Bay Shoreline, and Marin Coastal Mountains from September 4th through 8th, along with a Heat Advisory for the Central Coast, San Francisco, and coastal North Bay on September 6th. Several daily record high temperature records were shattered, along with a handful of monthly and all-time records. Triple digit temperatures were reported across a vast swath of the interior, with some sites reaching 110 degrees and higher. Reports of power outages, heat related illnesses and deaths were received. Counties opened/operated one or more cooling centers to provide relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Santa Clara County EMS reported 60 calls were received for heat-related illness.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The summer heat started a little early with Heat Advisories and Excessive Heat Warnings during the June 11-13th period. Maximum heat indices exceeded 105 across just about all of North and Central Texas. Ambient temperatures actually exceeded 105 for many counties, particularly along and west of the I-35 corridor on June 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees during the afternoon hours of June 11th-13th. The County was also under an Excessive Heat Warning on June 12th but did not technically reach criteria.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure developed over the area along with light offshore flow, allowing temperatures to soar into the 90s to low 100s for all areas, except parts of the immediate coastline. A head advisory was issued for all but coastal zones from late morning through the evening of June 21.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Downtown Napa and Santa Rosa reached 104 degrees. Several other cities in the valleys reached the low to mid 100s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure developed over the area along with light offshore flow, allowing temperatures to soar into the 90s to low 100s for all areas, except parts of the immediate coastline. A head advisory was issued for all but coastal zones from late morning through the evening of June 21.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: SFO airport had a max temperature of 98 degrees, breaking the daily record of 94 deg set in 1974. Oakland Airport reached 99 degrees. Most of the Bay Shoreline reached the mid to upper 90s.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat indices topped 110 degrees across southwest Indiana in the afternoon. Peak heat indices ranged from 110 at Evansville to 115 at Huntingburg. A hot and humid southwest wind flow ahead of a cold front brought temperatures up to the lower 90's. Dew points were exceptionally high, with readings in the lower 80's at most stations.

Another period of excessive heat occurred across southern Illinois. Heat indices peaked around 110 degrees on the 22nd, 23rd, and 24th. The peak heat index at Carbondale was 108 on the 22nd, 105 on the 23rd, and 107 on the 24th. Another large 500 mb high became stubbornly persistent across the southern states, from the Four Corners region to the Southeast. Underneath this high, daily high temperatures were in the lower to mid 90's. Overnight lows were mostly in the mid 70's.

Above normal temperatures and elevated dew points resulted in a period of very warm and humid conditions across southeast Georgia in late July. The Statesboro-Bulloch County Airport (KTBR) observed max heat index values in the upper 90s during the late July period. The heat and humidity caused two heat-related fatalities in Bulloch County.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Bulloch County Emergency Management confirmed two heat-related deaths in the county. The coroner reported that a couple, who were both in their eighties, died in a mobile home on Tall Timbers Lane in the Leefield community near Brooklet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A northward lifting warm front brought a hot and humid air mass to portions of eastern New York on July 28, 2022. Heat indices reached the mid-90s to lower 100s across the Hudson River Valley from the Capital District and points south. ||During the afternoon and early evening hours, showers and thunderstorms developed ahead of an approaching cold front. A couple of these storms became severe producing isolated wind damage across portions of Rensselaer and Columbia counties.

A ridge of high pressure in the middle and upper atmosphere developed over the south central United States during mid June. Unseasonably hot afternoon temperatures reaching the mid to upper 90s, combined with high humidity, resulted in heat index values in the 110 to 115 degree range across much of eastern Oklahoma on the 12th. At least nine people were treated for heat-related issues in Tulsa.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure amplified over the Western US at the end of June, affecting the Pacific Northwest. This resulted in the first heatwave across Western Washington, with high temperatures climbing well into the 80s and even 90s. In addition to the heat, cold water was also a concern as people looked for relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 87 degrees was set at the Quillayute airport on Saturday June 25. This broke the previous record of 86 degrees set in 2017.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 92 degrees was set at the Hoquiam airport on Saturday, June 25. This broke the previous record of 82 degrees set in 2017.||A record high temperature of 93 degrees was set at the Hoquiam airport on Sunday, June 26. This broke the previous record of 87 degrees set in 2021.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The summer heat started a little early with Heat Advisories and Excessive Heat Warnings during the June 11-13th period. Maximum heat indices exceeded 105 across just about all of North and Central Texas. Ambient temperatures actually exceeded 105 for many counties, particularly along and west of the I-35 corridor on June 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures near and over 105 degrees were reported in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Another period of excessive heat occurred across southern Illinois. Heat indices peaked around 110 degrees on the 22nd, 23rd, and 24th. The peak heat index at Carbondale was 108 on the 22nd, 105 on the 23rd, and 107 on the 24th. Another large 500 mb high became stubbornly persistent across the southern states, from the Four Corners region to the Southeast. Underneath this high, daily high temperatures were in the lower to mid 90's. Overnight lows were mostly in the mid 70's.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the end of June, a strong ridge of high pressure set up across the western United States, becoming centered over the Great Basin. This led to temperatures climbing slightly above normal across the Phoenix area, with the afternoon high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaking at 109 degrees on the 29th. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 10 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four heat-associated fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: For the end of June, a strong ridge of high pressure set up across the western United States, becoming centered over the Great Basin. This led to temperatures climbing slightly above normal across the Phoenix area, with the afternoon high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaking at 109 degrees on the 29th. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 10 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure built in across the Southwest heading into the middle part of June, bringing excessive heat conditions to the region. High temperatures in Phoenix officially approached or exceeded 110 degrees between June 8-12th, which is well above the seasonal normal. The hottest temperature during this timeframe occurred on the 11th when the high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked at 114 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 36 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.
Ambient temperatures at or above 103 along with heat indices at or above 105 were felt across most of North and Central Texas Thursday June 23 through Saturday June 25.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat indices between 105 and 110 were reached in Alvarado each afternoon from June 23 to June 25.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Maximum heat index values climbed to between 105 and 110 the afternoons of June 23 through June 25 at Cox Field Airport in Paris, TX.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure dominated the Four Corners region. This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across the Grand Valley. Conditions were exceptionally dry which translated to minimum humidities in the single digits to low teens.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 100 to 107 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure dominated the Four Corners region. This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across southeast Utah. Conditions were exceptionally dry which translated to minimum humidities in the single digits to low teens.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 103 to 110 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A ridge of high pressure dominated the Four Corners region. This resulted in scorching heat and dry weather across southeast Utah. Conditions were exceptionally dry which translated to minimum humidities in the single digits to low teens.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: High temperatures of 98 to 104 degrees were reported by various automated weather stations. On the evening of Sunday, July 17, Canyonlands National Park staff received a report of a missing male subject who was overdue after attempting a short hike from Elephant Hill in the Needles District that afternoon. The body of the missing hiker was later found on Tuesday, July 19. The hiker is suspected to have died from heat-related illness.

CZ_NAME: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure encompassed the Western CONUS from September 1st through 8th, leading to anomalously hot temperatures along the California coast, and even more extreme temperatures in interior valleys and all mountain zones, where very hot daytime temperatures combined with a lack of overnight cooling created extreme heat risk . Excessive Heat Warnings were issued for interior areas and mountains of Monterey/San Benito Counties for the period September 1st through 8th, and for interior valleys and mountain zones around the San Francisco Bay Area from September 4th through 8th. A combination of Heat Advisories and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for parts of Monterey Bay and its near coastal valleys, the San Francisco Bay Shoreline, and Marin Coastal Mountains from September 4th through 8th, along with a Heat Advisory for the Central Coast, San Francisco, and coastal North Bay on September 6th. Several daily record high temperature records were shattered, along with a handful of monthly and all-time records. Triple digit temperatures were reported across a vast swath of the interior, with some sites reaching 110 degrees and higher. Reports of power outages, heat related illnesses and deaths were received. Counties opened/operated one or more cooling centers to provide relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gilroy Coop site equaled its monthly record max temperature of 112 deg., set in 2017. It also set a new daily record, breaking the previous record of 106 deg., set in 2020. SJC Airport set a new daily max temperature record of 104 deg., breaking the previous record of 99 deg. set in 2008.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Livermore Coop site set an all time record of 116 deg., breaking the previous all time record of 115 deg. set in 1950. Livermore ASOS reported a max temperature of 113 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The summer heat started a little early with Heat Advisories and Excessive Heat Warnings during the June 11-13th period. Maximum heat indices exceeded 105 across just about all of North and Central Texas. Ambient temperatures actually exceeded 105 for many counties, particularly along and west of the I-35 corridor on June 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures near 105 degrees were reported in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The summer heat started a little early with Heat Advisories and Excessive Heat Warnings during the June 11-13th period. Maximum heat indices exceeded 105 across just about all of North and Central Texas. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Temperatures near 105 degrees were reported in the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A prolonged heat wave gripped most of southern Illinois for several days. From the 4th to the 8th, peak afternoon heat indices ranged from 105 to 120 degrees. The exception was the Interstate 64 corridor from Mount Vernon to Mount Carmel, where the dangerous levels of heat lasted only from the 4th until the 6th. The hottest day in southern Illinois was the 5th, when the heat index peaked between 111 and 120 at all airport sites. During this heat wave, a sprawling 500 mb high covered most of the southern states from the southern Plains to the southern Appalachian Mountains. Beneath this large 500 mb high, daily high temperatures frequently soared into the mid and upper 90's. Night-time temperatures were quite warm. Carbondale set a daily record warm low temperature of 79 degrees on the 6th.

Another period of excessive heat occurred across southeast Missouri. Heat indices peaked around 110 degrees on the 22nd, 23rd, and 24th. The peak heat index at Cape Girardeau was 115 on the 22nd, 109 on the 23rd, and 114 on the 24th. Another large 500 mb high became stubbornly persistent across the southern states, from the Four Corners region to the Southeast. Underneath this high, daily high temperatures were in the mid to upper 90's. Overnight lows were in the lower to mid 70's.

A strong ridge of high pressure encompassed the Western CONUS from September 1st through 8th, leading to anomalously hot temperatures along the California coast, and even more extreme temperatures in interior valleys and all mountain zones, where very hot daytime temperatures combined with a lack of overnight cooling created extreme heat risk . Excessive Heat Warnings were issued for interior areas and mountains of Monterey/San Benito Counties for the period September 1st through 8th, and for interior valleys and mountain zones around the San Francisco Bay Area from September 4th through 8th. A combination of Heat Advisories and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for parts of Monterey Bay and its near coastal valleys, the San Francisco Bay Shoreline, and Marin Coastal Mountains from September 4th through 8th, along with a Heat Advisory for the Central Coast, San Francisco, and coastal North Bay on September 6th. Several daily record high temperature records were shattered, along with a handful of monthly and all-time records. Triple digit temperatures were reported across a vast swath of the interior, with some sites reaching 110 degrees and higher. Reports of power outages, heat related illnesses and deaths were received. Counties opened/operated one or more cooling centers to provide relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Forty cooling centers opened in Alameda County Bay Shoreline communities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High dewpoint temperatures combined with very hot daytime high temperatures on July 20th, resulting in heat index values exceeding 111 degrees in Hidalgo, Starr, and Zapata Counties during the afternoon.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Linn-San Manuel Texas Mesonet site (LSRT2) first recorded heat index values reaching or exceeding 111 degrees around 2:46PM CDT. Heat index values then remained above 111 degrees through 4:46PM CDT, topping out around 112 degrees during this time. No heat-related injuries or fatalities were reported as of this writing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The summer heat started a little early with Heat Advisories and Excessive Heat Warnings during the June 11-13th period. Maximum heat indices exceeded 105 across just about all of North and Central Texas. Ambient temperatures actually exceeded 105 for many counties, particularly along and west of the I-35 corridor on June 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees during the afternoon hours of June 11th-13th. The County was also under an Excessive Heat Warning on June 12th.

Carbondale set a daily record warm low temperature of 79 degrees on the 6th.

The exception was the Interstate 64 corridor from Mount Vernon to Mount Carmel, where the dangerous levels of heat lasted only from the 4th until the 6th. For the end of June, a strong ridge of high pressure set up across the western United States, becoming centered over the Great Basin. This led to temperatures climbing slightly above normal across the Phoenix area, with the afternoon high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaking at 109 degrees on the 29th. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 10 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Ambient temperatures at or above 103 along with heat indices at or above 105 were felt across most of North and Central Texas Thursday June 23 through Saturday June 25.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The high temperature reached 103 on the afternoons of June 24 and June 25 at the Remote Automatic Weather Station on the Fort Hood Military base.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure encompassed the Western CONUS from September 1st through 8th, leading to anomalously hot temperatures along the California coast, and even more extreme temperatures in interior valleys and all mountain zones, where very hot daytime temperatures combined with a lack of overnight cooling created extreme heat risk . Excessive Heat Warnings were issued for interior areas and mountains of Monterey/San Benito Counties for the period September 1st through 8th, and for interior valleys and mountain zones around the San Francisco Bay Area from September 4th through 8th. A combination of Heat Advisories and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for parts of Monterey Bay and its near coastal valleys, the San Francisco Bay Shoreline, and Marin Coastal Mountains from September 4th through 8th, along with a Heat Advisory for the Central Coast, San Francisco, and coastal North Bay on September 6th. Several daily record high temperature records were shattered, along with a handful of monthly and all-time records. Triple digit temperatures were reported across a vast swath of the interior, with some sites reaching 110 degrees and higher. Reports of power outages, heat related illnesses and deaths were received. Counties opened/operated one or more cooling centers to provide relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Santa Rosa Coop site set a new monthly max temperature record of 112 deg., breaking the previous record of 110 deg recorded in 2020, 2017, and 1971. Napa Coop site set a new daily max temperature record of 109 deg., breaking the previous record of 102 deg. set in 2020. Kentfield Coop site set a new daily record of 107 deg., breaking the previous record of 103 deg., set in 1950.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The summer heat started a little early with Heat Advisories and Excessive Heat Warnings during the June 11-13th period. Maximum heat indices exceeded 105 across just about all of North and Central Texas. Ambient temperatures actually exceeded 105 for many counties, particularly along and west of the I-35 corridor on June 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees during the afternoon hours of June 11th-13th. The County was also under an Excessive Heat Warning on June 12th.

Another episode of hazardous heat impacted far western Kentucky, mainly west of Kentucky Lake. Peak heat indices on the afternoons of the 26th and 27th were around 105 degrees. Hot and humid southwest winds persisted ahead of a cold front as it moved east from the Plains toward the Mississippi Valley. Actual high temperatures were in the lower 90's.

CZ_NAME: WEST SIDE MOUNTAINS NORTH OF HIGHWAY 198
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure strengthened over the area between June 9 and June 11.  This resulted in temperatures rising to well above normal readings by June 10 with some locations approaching record highs.  Heat Advisories were issued for the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Kern River Valley and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for the Kern County Desert areas.  The heat continued on June 11 then a low pressure system moved into the Pacific Northwest on June 12 which pushed a cold front through the area resulting in temperatures cooling by a few degrees on June 12 and plunging to slightly below normal levels by June 13.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 104 degrees on June 10 and June 11.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Warm conditions associated with a ridge of high pressure building across the Southeast United States in combination with high dewpoint temperatures along coastal areas led to conditions favorable for heat related illnesses during afternoon hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Broadcast media reported several recruits at Parris Island experienced heat stress during the afternoon, including one individual who needed to be treated at Beaufort Memorial Hospital for a heat related illness. The Beaufort MCAS calculated a heat index value of 111 degrees fahrenheit at 2 PM.

A strong upper level ridge of high pressure developed across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, producing a record-breaking early season heat wave. Evansville broke two daily record highs and three daily record warm lows. Evansville's low of 81 degrees on the 14th tied its all-time warmest low temperature in the month of June. Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees starting on June 13 and continued through June 16. The most oppressive day was June 13th, when dewpoints in the mid 70's to around 80 produced heat index values of 110 to 115.

A strong upper level ridge of high pressure developed across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, producing a record-breaking early season heat wave. Along and west of a line from Mount Vernon to Marion to Metropolis, heat index values exceeded 105 degrees starting on June 12 and continuing through June 16. East of that line, heat indices exceeded 105 degrees from the 13th to the 16th. The most oppressive day was June 13, when dewpoints in the mid 70's to around 80 produced heat index values of 110 to 115. Carbondale broke one daily record high temperature and three daily record warm low temperatures. Paducah, KY (across the Ohio River from Metropolis, IL) tied its June all-time warmest low temperature of 81 degrees. This was only the 2nd time on record that Paducah observed four consecutive days reaching 95 degrees this early in the season (before June 20). The other occurrence was back in 1952, with 8 straight days at or above 95 degrees from June 9-16.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure centered over the Great Basin between June 25 and June 27 provided for a period of much above normal temperatures across the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills, Sierra foothills and the Kern River Valley.  Daytime high temperatures generally ranged from 104 to 108 Degrees on each of these days.  The high began to weaken on June 28 and temperatures began to trend downward during the last few days of June.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 104 and 108 degrees between June 10 and June 12.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions developed across northwest Indiana during the afternoon of June 13th and continued through the afternoon of June 15th.  The highest heat indices were reached during the afternoon of June 14th and included 109 degrees at Gary Airport and at the Indiana Dunes; 106 degrees at Valparaiso Airport and 105 degrees at Rensselaer Airport.

Heat indices peaked around 105 degrees during the afternoon. Some specific peak heat index values included 105 degrees at Henderson, 106 at Owensboro, 104 at Hopkinsville, 109 at Princeton and Murray, and 103 at Paducah. The heat and humidity occurred just ahead of a weak cold front as it crossed the lower Ohio Valley and southeast Missouri.
