A strong upper level ridge of high pressure developed across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, producing a record-breaking early season heat wave. Along and west of a line from Mount Vernon to Marion to Metropolis, heat index values exceeded 105 degrees starting on June 12 and continuing through June 16. East of that line, heat indices exceeded 105 degrees from the 13th to the 16th. The most oppressive day was June 13, when dewpoints in the mid 70's to around 80 produced heat index values of 110 to 115. Carbondale broke one daily record high temperature and three daily record warm low temperatures. Paducah, KY (across the Ohio River from Metropolis, IL) tied its June all-time warmest low temperature of 81 degrees. This was only the 2nd time on record that Paducah observed four consecutive days reaching 95 degrees this early in the season (before June 20). The other occurrence was back in 1952, with 8 straight days at or above 95 degrees from June 9-16.

CZ_NAME: LAKE MEAD/LAKE MOHAVE NATIONAL RECREATION AREA
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Building high pressure pushed temperatures close to records over much of the Mojave Desert. Twelve people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes during and shortly after the heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached four days in a row.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Building high pressure pushed temperatures close to records over much of the Mojave Desert. Twelve people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes during and shortly after the heat wave.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached three days in a row.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: One person died in Death Valley of heat-related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One person died in Death Valley of heat-related causes. The date of death is estimated.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two people died in Las Vegas of heat-related causes.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of high pressure strengthened over the area between June 9 and June 11.  This resulted in temperatures rising to well above normal readings by June 10 with some locations approaching record highs.  Heat Advisories were issued for the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Kern River Valley and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for the Kern County Desert areas.  The heat continued on June 11 then a low pressure system moved into the Pacific Northwest on June 12 which pushed a cold front through the area resulting in temperatures cooling by a few degrees on June 12 and plunging to slightly below normal levels by June 13.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 104 degrees on June 10 and June 11.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure built in across the Southwest heading into the middle part of June, bringing excessive heat conditions to the region. High temperatures in Phoenix officially approached or exceeded 110 degrees between June 8-12th, which is well above the seasonal normal. The hottest temperature during this timeframe occurred on the 11th when the high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked at 114 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 36 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.

CZ_NAME: SAN BERNARDINO AND RIVERSIDE COUNTY VALLEYS - THE INLAND EMPIRE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple days of excessive heat occurred across inland areas for several days June 9-13. Multiple wildfires were reported during this time frame, including fires near Wrightwood, Oceanside and along the US-Mexico border.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: San Jacinto recorded a high temperature of 102 degrees on June 10, tying the previous record of 102 set in 2019.

A strong ridge of high pressure encompassed the Western CONUS from September 1st through 8th, leading to anomalously hot temperatures along the California coast, and even more extreme temperatures in interior valleys and all mountain zones, where very hot daytime temperatures combined with a lack of overnight cooling created extreme heat risk . Excessive Heat Warnings were issued for interior areas and mountains of Monterey/San Benito Counties for the period September 1st through 8th, and for interior valleys and mountain zones around the San Francisco Bay Area from September 4th through 8th. A combination of Heat Advisories and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for parts of Monterey Bay and its near coastal valleys, the San Francisco Bay Shoreline, and Marin Coastal Mountains from September 4th through 8th, along with a Heat Advisory for the Central Coast, San Francisco, and coastal North Bay on September 6th. Several daily record high temperature records were shattered, along with a handful of monthly and all-time records. Triple digit temperatures were reported across a vast swath of the interior, with some sites reaching 110 degrees and higher. Reports of power outages, heat related illnesses and deaths were received. Counties opened/operated one or more cooling centers to provide relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Santa Rosa set an all-time record high temperature of 115 deg, beating its previous record 113 deg set in 1913. Downtown Napa set an all-time record high temperature of 114 deg, beating its previous record 113 deg set in 1961.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple days of excessive heat occurred across inland areas for several days June 9-13. Multiple wildfires were reported during this time frame, including fires near Wrightwood, Oceanside and along the US-Mexico border.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As a strong area of high pressure built over New Mexico on June 11, 2022, it led to soaring daytime temperatures. High temperatures during the afternoon reached well into the triple digits with some of the hottest temperatures experienced so far this year. Tucumcari reached a high temperature of 112 degrees Fahrenheit which actually set a new all time high temperature record which was previously 110 degrees Fahrenheit in 2020. Despite this high pressure system's presence, not all of the moisture was scoured out. Enough mid-level moisture was present to allow for isolated dry shower and thunderstorm activity. With very dry conditions in the low-levels, however, this activity produced very strong downburst winds. Las Vegas recorded a 59 mph wind gust with this dry activity.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An ASOS station near Roswell measured a high temperature of 111 degrees Fahrenheit. This beat the old daily record of 106 degrees Fahrenheit set in just 2021.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Medical professionals and police determined that a toddler had died due to heat after being left in a vehicle in the Clark Elementary School parking lot. The child was discovered around 5pm. The high temperature in Clark was 89 degrees, as recorded by the Clark COOP Observer, which is about 15 degrees above normal for September 6th.

This was only the 2nd time on record that Paducah observed four consecutive days reaching 95 degrees this early in the season (before June 20). The other occurrence was back in 1952, with 8 straight days at or above 95 degrees from June 9-16.

A large area of high pressure strengthened over the area between June 9 and June 11.  This resulted in temperatures rising to well above normal readings by June 10 with some locations approaching record highs.  Heat Advisories were issued for the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills and Kern River Valley and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for the Kern County Desert areas.  The heat continued on June 11 then a low pressure system moved into the Pacific Northwest on June 12 which pushed a cold front through the area resulting in temperatures cooling by a few degrees on June 12 and plunging to slightly below normal levels by June 13.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 100 and 104 degrees on June 10 and June 11.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following a northward-progressing warm frontal zone, a strong, broad, subtropical upper-level ridge built over central Indiana by June 14th.  Associated heat and at times record-high dewpoints (for June) then lasted for several days across the region.  Morning lows were mainly in the mid-70s to low 80s, while afternoon highs in the mid-90s were common; dewpoints climbed into the upper 70s on June 14th, and stayed in the mid-70s through June 16th.  Excessive Heat criteria of 110 degree or higher heat indices was reached during the afternoon and/or late day hours of June 14th, in 9 of central Indiana's 39 zones between far southwestern counties, southeastern portions of the Indianapolis Metro area, and two north-central counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Criteria was reached from maximum heat index values reaching 110 degrees on June 14th over central and eastern portions of Johnson County. Heat index values were from measured temperature and dewpoint at the OKK AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following a northward-progressing warm frontal zone, a strong, broad, subtropical upper-level ridge built over central Indiana by June 14th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: Criteria was reached from maximum heat index values exceeding 110 degrees on June 14th over all but far northeastern portions of Knox County.  Heat index values are estimated from combination of observed maximum temperature of 98 degrees at Vincennes 5 NE station and estimated dewpoints from proximity to nearby LWV ASOS and DCY AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure became situated over the Four Corners region, leading to dangerous temperatures as well as excessive heat conditions at times across the Phoenix area. Afternoon highs in Phoenix climbed well above normal during this time with temperatures peaking on the 11th at 115 degrees. Overnight temperatures provided little relief from the heat as lows in Phoenix remained in the low 90s for several mornings. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 55 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.

A large area of high pressure centered over the Great Basin between June 25 and June 27 provided for a period of much above normal temperatures across the San Joaquin Valley, West Side Hills, Sierra foothills and the Kern River Valley.  Daytime high temperatures generally ranged from 104 to 108 Degrees on each of these days.  The high began to weaken on June 28 and temperatures began to trend downward during the last few days of June.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Daytime highs ranged between 104 and 108 degrees between June 10 and June 12.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge brought warm temperatures region wide for the first half of September. This resulted in record high temperatures set on September 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Quillayute ASOS recorded a record high temperature on September 10th of 92 degrees, this beat the previous recorded back in 2020 of 89 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge brought warm temperatures region wide for the first half of September. This resulted in record high temperatures set on September 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seattle-Tacoma Airport ASOS recorded a new maximum temperature on September 10th of 92 degrees, this beats the previous record in 2020 of 91 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge brought warm temperatures region wide for the first half of September. This resulted in record high temperatures set on September 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hoquiam ASOS recorded a new maximum temperature of 91 degrees on September 10th, previously beating the record in 2007 of 88 degrees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge brought record heat area wide in late September.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 79 was set at Bellingham WA airport today. This ties the old record of 79 set in 1949.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level ridge brought record heat area wide in late September.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A record high temperature of 86 was set at Olympia WA Airport on September 26th. This breaks the old record of 83 set in 2016.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions developed across northern Illinois during the afternoon of June 13th and continued through the afternoon of June 15th.  High temperatures reached the middle to upper 90s on all three days.  Midway Airport reached 100 degrees on June 14th and June 15th.  The highest heat indices were reached during the afternoon of June 13th and included 115 degrees at Joliet Airport; 114 degrees at Morris Airport; 113 degrees at Peru Airport; 111 degrees at Dixon Airport, Kankakee Airport, Pontiac Airport and Lewis University Airport in Romeoville and 109 degrees at Sugar Grove Airport.  Peak afternoon heat indices reached 105 to 109 degrees on the afternoons of June 14th and June 15th.  A 33 year old man died from heat exposure in Will County on June 14th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure developed across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, producing a record-breaking early season heat wave. Along and west of a line from Mount Vernon to Marion to Metropolis, heat index values exceeded 105 degrees starting on June 12 and continuing through June 16. East of that line, heat indices exceeded 105 degrees from the 13th to the 16th. The most oppressive day was June 13, when dewpoints in the mid 70's to around 80 produced heat index values of 110 to 115. Carbondale broke one daily record high temperature and three daily record warm low temperatures. Paducah, KY (across the Ohio River from Metropolis, IL) tied its June all-time warmest low temperature of 81 degrees. This was only the 2nd time on record that Paducah observed four consecutive days reaching 95 degrees this early in the season (before June 20). The other occurrence was back in 1952, with 8 straight days at or above 95 degrees from June 9-16.

A hot and humid airmass enveloping the region produced heat indices near or exceeding 100F over much of the west and portions of central Upper Mi from the 20th into 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated heat indices soared above 100F across the county on the afternoon of the 20th and stayed above 80F through the evening hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Estimated heat indices soared to 95 to 105F across northern Houghton County on the afternoon of the 20th and stayed above 80F through the evening hours.

High pressure over interior northern California brought widespread moderate to locally high heat risk to the region. Triple digit temperatures were observed across much of the Valley on June 10th and 11th with the hottest temperatures on June 10th. A daily high temperature record was tied in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: ASOS reported high temperature readings ranged from 100 to 104 degrees during the event. The warmest high temperatures were observed on Friday the 10th and reached 104 degrees at the Marysville Airport. One cooling center was open through 8:00 pm in Yuba County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure developed across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, producing a record-breaking early season heat wave. Along and west of a line from Mount Vernon to Marion to Metropolis, heat index values exceeded 105 degrees starting on June 12 and continuing through June 16. East of that line, heat indices exceeded 105 degrees from the 13th to the 16th. The most oppressive day was June 13, when dewpoints in the mid 70's to around 80 produced heat index values of 110 to 115. Carbondale broke one daily record high temperature and three daily record warm low temperatures. Paducah, KY (across the Ohio River from Metropolis, IL) tied its June all-time warmest low temperature of 81 degrees. This was only the 2nd time on record that Paducah observed four consecutive days reaching 95 degrees this early in the season (before June 20). The other occurrence was back in 1952, with 8 straight days at or above 95 degrees from June 9-16.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure over interior northern California brought widespread moderate to locally high heat risk to the region. Triple digit temperatures were observed across much of the Valley on June 10th and 11th with the hottest temperatures on June 10th. A daily high temperature record was tied in the area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: ASOS reported high temperature readings ranged from 94 to 101 degrees during the event. The warmest high temperatures were observed on Friday the 10th and reached 101 degrees in Glenn County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure developed across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, producing a record-breaking early season heat wave. Low temperatures in the lower 80's were observed in several locations, setting monthly records. Paducah tied its June all-time warmest low temperature of 81 degrees. There was one daily record high temperature that was broken at Paducah. This was only the 2nd time on record that Paducah observed four consecutive days reaching 95 degrees this early in the season (before June 20). The other occurrence was back in 1952 with eight straight days at or above 95 degrees from June 9-16. Along and southwest of a line from Paducah through Kentucky Lake to Cadiz, heat index values exceeded 105 degrees starting on June 12 and continuing through June 16. Northeast of that line, heat indices peaked above 105 starting on June 13. The most oppressive day was June 13th, when dewpoints in the mid 70's to around 80 produced heat index values of 106 to 116.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure built in across the Southwest heading into the middle part of June, bringing excessive heat conditions to the region. High temperatures in Phoenix officially approached or exceeded 110 degrees between June 8-12th, which is well above the seasonal normal. The hottest temperature during this timeframe occurred on the 11th when the high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked at 114 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 36 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.

Following a northward-progressing warm frontal zone, a strong, broad, subtropical upper-level ridge built over central Indiana by June 14th.  Associated heat and at times record-high dewpoints (for June) then lasted for several days across the region.  Morning lows were mainly in the mid-70s to low 80s, while afternoon highs in the mid-90s were common; dewpoints climbed into the upper 70s on June 14th, and stayed in the mid-70s through June 16th.  Excessive Heat criteria of 110 degree or higher heat indices was reached during the afternoon and/or late day hours of June 14th, in 9 of central Indiana's 39 zones between far southwestern counties, southeastern portions of the Indianapolis Metro area, and two north-central counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Criteria was reached from maximum heat index values exceeding 110 degrees on June 14th over roughly the southwestern half of Vigo County.  Heat index values were from measured temperature and dewpoint at the HUF Terre Haute ASOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heat and humidity combined to produce oppressive heat indices that exceeded 105 degrees across much of the area on the 11th through the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: First responders responded to at least 5 heat related illness calls, with at least one person needing to be transported to the hospital.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure encompassed the Western CONUS from September 1st through 8th, leading to anomalously hot temperatures along the California coast, and even more extreme temperatures in interior valleys and all mountain zones, where very hot daytime temperatures combined with a lack of overnight cooling created extreme heat risk . Excessive Heat Warnings were issued for interior areas and mountains of Monterey/San Benito Counties for the period September 1st through 8th, and for interior valleys and mountain zones around the San Francisco Bay Area from September 4th through 8th. A combination of Heat Advisories and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for parts of Monterey Bay and its near coastal valleys, the San Francisco Bay Shoreline, and Marin Coastal Mountains from September 4th through 8th, along with a Heat Advisory for the Central Coast, San Francisco, and coastal North Bay on September 6th. Several daily record high temperature records were shattered, along with a handful of monthly and all-time records. Triple digit temperatures were reported across a vast swath of the interior, with some sites reaching 110 degrees and higher. Reports of power outages, heat related illnesses and deaths were received. Counties opened/operated one or more cooling centers to provide relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Redwood City tied its all-time record high temperature of 110 deg set in 1972. It also beat its monthly record 108 deg set in 2020.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple days of excessive heat occurred across inland areas for several days June 9-13. Multiple wildfires were reported during this time frame, including fires near Wrightwood, Oceanside and along the US-Mexico border.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Idyllwild broke high temperatures three days in a row from June 9-11.||June 9: 91 degrees, tying previous record of 91 degrees (2013).|June 10: 92 degrees, breaking previous record of 89 degrees (2019).|June 11: 91 degrees, breaking previous record of 90 degrees (1979).

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot and humid conditions developed across northern Illinois during the afternoon of June 13th and continued through the afternoon of June 15th.  High temperatures reached the middle to upper 90s on all three days.  Midway Airport reached 100 degrees on June 14th and June 15th.  The highest heat indices were reached during the afternoon of June 13th and included 115 degrees at Joliet Airport; 114 degrees at Morris Airport; 113 degrees at Peru Airport; 111 degrees at Dixon Airport, Kankakee Airport, Pontiac Airport and Lewis University Airport in Romeoville and 109 degrees at Sugar Grove Airport.  Peak afternoon heat indices reached 105 to 109 degrees on the afternoons of June 14th and June 15th.  A 33 year old man died from heat exposure in Will County on June 14th.

A strong upper level ridge of high pressure developed across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, producing a record-breaking early season heat wave. Low temperatures in the lower 80's were observed in several locations, setting monthly records. Paducah tied its June all-time warmest low temperature of 81 degrees. There was one daily record high temperature that was broken at Paducah. This was only the 2nd time on record that Paducah observed four consecutive days reaching 95 degrees this early in the season (before June 20). The other occurrence was back in 1952 with eight straight days at or above 95 degrees from June 9-16. Along and southwest of a line from Paducah through Kentucky Lake to Cadiz, heat index values exceeded 105 degrees starting on June 12 and continuing through June 16. Northeast of that line, heat indices peaked above 105 starting on June 13. The most oppressive day was June 13th, when dewpoints in the mid 70's to around 80 produced heat index values of 106 to 116.

Persistent southwest winds brought hot and humid conditions to southern WI. Heat index values well over 100 degrees occurred. Cooling centers were opened in some communities. Two heat related fatalities occurred in Milwaukee.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Heat Index values ranging from 105 to 113 degrees on June 14th and rising into the lower 100's once again on June 15th. Milwaukee County Medical Examiner determined that a 39 year old female and a 89 year old male died from heat related causes. The female was found in her house and the gentleman was found collapsed in his backyard.

A 590 DAM ridge at 500 mb built over CA Thursday June 9 into Friday June 10, leading to rapid warming of the airmass and daytime surface temperatures reaching into the 90s to over 100 degrees over a large swath of the state away from the coast. A heat advisory was issued covering interior portions (mountains and valleys) of the SF Bay Area and Central Coast for June 10 from 11 AM until 10 PM.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Sonoma County Airport reached a high of 102 degrees.

CZ_NAME: SOUTHERN SALINAS VALLEY / ARROYO SECO / LAKE SAN ANTONIO
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure encompassed the Western CONUS from September 1st through 8th, leading to anomalously hot temperatures along the California coast, and even more extreme temperatures in interior valleys and all mountain zones, where very hot daytime temperatures combined with a lack of overnight cooling created extreme heat risk . Excessive Heat Warnings were issued for interior areas and mountains of Monterey/San Benito Counties for the period September 1st through 8th, and for interior valleys and mountain zones around the San Francisco Bay Area from September 4th through 8th. A combination of Heat Advisories and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for parts of Monterey Bay and its near coastal valleys, the San Francisco Bay Shoreline, and Marin Coastal Mountains from September 4th through 8th, along with a Heat Advisory for the Central Coast, San Francisco, and coastal North Bay on September 6th. Several daily record high temperature records were shattered, along with a handful of monthly and all-time records. Triple digit temperatures were reported across a vast swath of the interior, with some sites reaching 110 degrees and higher. Reports of power outages, heat related illnesses and deaths were received. Counties opened/operated one or more cooling centers to provide relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: King City reported an all-time record high temperature of 116 deg, beating the previous record 115 deg set in 2017.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Following a northward-progressing warm frontal zone, a strong, broad, subtropical upper-level ridge built over central Indiana by June 14th.  Associated heat and at times record-high dewpoints (for June) then lasted for several days across the region.  Morning lows were mainly in the mid-70s to low 80s, while afternoon highs in the mid-90s were common; dewpoints climbed into the upper 70s on June 14th, and stayed in the mid-70s through June 16th.  Excessive Heat criteria of 110 degree or higher heat indices was reached during the afternoon and/or late day hours of June 14th, in 9 of central Indiana's 39 zones between far southwestern counties, southeastern portions of the Indianapolis Metro area, and two north-central counties.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Criteria was reached from maximum heat index values exceeding 110 degrees on June 14th over roughly the northern and northeastern half of Johnson County.  Heat index values were from measured temperature and dewpoint at the HFY AWOS.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Criteria was reached from maximum heat index values reaching 110 degrees on June 14th over southern portions of Knox County.  Heat index values are estimated from combination of observed maximum temperature of 97 degrees at Washington 1 W station and dewpoints from nearby ASOS/AWOS.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge of high pressure developed across the Ohio and Tennessee Valleys, producing a record-breaking early season heat wave. Evansville broke two daily record highs and three daily record warm lows. Evansville's low of 81 degrees on the 14th tied its all-time warmest low temperature in the month of June. Heat index values exceeded 105 degrees starting on June 13 and continued through June 16. The most oppressive day was June 13th, when dewpoints in the mid 70's to around 80 produced heat index values of 110 to 115.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Excessive Heat Warning criteria were reached four days in a row.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong upper level ridge situated over the Desert Southwest led to well above normal temperatures along with excessive heat conditions at times. Temperatures during this time at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked on the 16th at 114 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 64 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven fatalities (5 direct and 2 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

Overnight temperatures provided little relief from the heat as lows in Phoenix remained in the low 90s for several mornings. A strong ridge of high pressure built in across the Southwest heading into the middle part of June, bringing excessive heat conditions to the region. High temperatures in Phoenix officially approached or exceeded 110 degrees between June 8-12th, which is well above the seasonal normal. The hottest temperature during this timeframe occurred on the 11th when the high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked at 114 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 36 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.

A strong ridge of high pressure encompassed the Western CONUS from September 1st through 8th, leading to anomalously hot temperatures along the California coast, and even more extreme temperatures in interior valleys and all mountain zones, where very hot daytime temperatures combined with a lack of overnight cooling created extreme heat risk . Excessive Heat Warnings were issued for interior areas and mountains of Monterey/San Benito Counties for the period September 1st through 8th, and for interior valleys and mountain zones around the San Francisco Bay Area from September 4th through 8th. A combination of Heat Advisories and an Excessive Heat Warning was issued for parts of Monterey Bay and its near coastal valleys, the San Francisco Bay Shoreline, and Marin Coastal Mountains from September 4th through 8th, along with a Heat Advisory for the Central Coast, San Francisco, and coastal North Bay on September 6th. Several daily record high temperature records were shattered, along with a handful of monthly and all-time records. Triple digit temperatures were reported across a vast swath of the interior, with some sites reaching 110 degrees and higher. Reports of power outages, heat related illnesses and deaths were received. Counties opened/operated one or more cooling centers to provide relief from the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Half Moon Bay set a daily record high temperature of 81 deg, beating its previous record 80 deg set in 2004.

CZ_NAME: SANTA CLARA VALLEY INCLUDING SAN JOSE
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure encompassed the Western CONUS from September 1st through 8th, leading to anomalously hot temperatures along the California coast, and even more extreme temperatures in interior valleys and all mountain zones, where very hot daytime temperatures combined with a lack of overnight cooling created extreme heat risk . Excessive Heat Warnings were issued for interior areas and mountains of Monterey/San Benito Counties for the period September 1st through 8th, and for interior valleys and mountain zones around the San Francisco Bay Area from September 4th through 8th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: San Jose Airport set an all-time record high temperature of 109 deg, beating the previous record 108 deg set in 2017. Gilroy coop site set a monthly high temperature record of 113 deg, beating the previous record 112 deg set the previous day.

Weak ridging during the start of July led to temperatures climbing slightly above normal. Temperatures at Phoenix Sky Harbor saw readings climb up to 109 degrees on the 3rd. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 18 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two indirect fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High pressure centered over the central CONUS retrograded westward during the 6-7th time frame, leading to temperatures in Phoenix topping out at 107 degrees each day. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 4 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

Afternoon highs in Phoenix climbed well above normal during this time with temperatures peaking on the 11th at 115 degrees. Overnight temperatures provided little relief from the heat as lows in Phoenix remained in the low 90s for several mornings. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 55 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

Anomalously strong high pressure built across the season pushed thermometers across the region 10-20 degrees above seasonal averages that broke several high-temperature records across parts of California and Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Total number of days in September with at least 100 degrees: 8 days. Prior to 2022, only 8 days reached or exceeded 100 degrees in September through the ENTIRE climate history of Reno, which goes back to 1888. This far exceeded the previous record of 3   days in September 2017 with highs at least 100F.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong ridge of high pressure built in across the Southwest heading into the middle part of June, bringing excessive heat conditions to the region. High temperatures in Phoenix officially approached or exceeded 110 degrees between June 8-12th, which is well above the seasonal normal. The hottest temperature during this timeframe occurred on the 11th when the high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked at 114 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 36 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.

Anomalously strong high pressure built across the season pushed thermometers across the region 10-20 degrees above seasonal averages that broke several high-temperature records across parts of California and Nevada.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Warmest September Temperature: 106F. This surpassed the highest temperature ever reported in September (and even August), and was equal to the 4th hottest day in  Reno`s climate history (only surpassed by three days with 108F on July 10-11, 2002 and July 5, 2007). Warmest minimum temperature for any September day: 69F on  the 7th, surpassing the previous record of 67F.

Hot temperatures 5 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in the western two thirds of Pima County on June 22 and 23. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for three individuals found in the desert, one in western Pima County and two on the Tohono O'odham Nation.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures nearly 10 degrees above normal occurred on June 23 with low temperatures in the lower 80s, causing the High Heat Risk category to be reached. Ajo topped out at 110 degrees and Organ Pipe National Monument reached 108. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found in the desert on the Cabeza Prieta National Wildlife Refuge.

An amplified ridge of high pressure became situated over the western CONUS, leading to above normal temperatures in Phoenix going into the end of September. Temperatures during this time topped out between 101-105 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 4 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One indirect fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomalously strong ridge of high pressure, with 500 mb heights around 594 dm, was parked over the western CONUS for the start of September. This resulted in well above normal temperatures as well as excessive heat conditions at times. Temperatures during this time in Phoenix officially peaked at 110 degrees on the 6th, while daily highs leading up to the 6th were around 108-109 degrees. Overnight temperatures during this time provided little relief from the heat as morning low temperatures only bottomed out in the upper 80s. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 25 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time. One of these fatalities was that of a hiker who died due to the heat after hiking Spur Cross Trail near Cave Creek.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Two direct fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

An anomalously strong ridge of high pressure over the Desert Southwest persisted into the latter part of July, leading to temperatures in excess of 110 degrees in Phoenix most days during this time. Temperatures during this time period peaked on the 22nd with Phoenix Sky Harbor recording a high of 114 degrees. Overnight temperatures provided little relief from the heat as morning lows remained in the 90s for several days. On the 22nd, the morning low temperature only cooled down to 95 degrees in Phoenix. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 81 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One direct fatality was reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the early afternoon, 6 hikers were 4 miles in on Spur Cross Trail when they became lost and ran out of water. The hikers' phones were also dead and had to borrow someone else's phone to call for help. After calling for help, first responders were able to rescue the hikers and airlift them off the trail. One hiker was taken to the hospital but did not survive. A Scottsdale Fire Captain said the individual died due to heat exhaustion and heat stroke. The Maricopa County Office of the Medical Examiner listed the primary cause of death as dehydration and heat exposure. Temperatures in the early afternoon were around 103-105 degrees.

A strong ridge of high pressure built in across the Southwest heading into the middle part of June, bringing excessive heat conditions to the region. High temperatures in Phoenix officially approached or exceeded 110 degrees between June 8-12th, which is well above the seasonal normal. The hottest temperature during this timeframe occurred on the 11th when the high temperature at Phoenix Sky Harbor peaked at 114 degrees. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 36 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.

An anomalously strong ridge of high pressure over the Desert Southwest persisted into the latter part of July, leading to temperatures in excess of 110 degrees in Phoenix most days during this time. Temperatures during this time period peaked on the 22nd with Phoenix Sky Harbor recording a high of 114 degrees. Overnight temperatures provided little relief from the heat as morning lows remained in the 90s for several days. On the 22nd, the morning low temperature only cooled down to 95 degrees in Phoenix. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 81 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven fatalities (2 direct and 5 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 81 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three indirect fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An anomalously strong ridge of high pressure, with 500 mb heights around 594 dm, was parked over the western CONUS for the start of September. This resulted in well above normal temperatures as well as excessive heat conditions at times. Temperatures during this time in Phoenix officially peaked at 110 degrees on the 6th, while daily highs leading up to the 6th were around 108-109 degrees. Overnight temperatures during this time provided little relief from the heat as morning low temperatures only bottomed out in the upper 80s. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 25 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this time. One of these fatalities was that of a hiker who died due to the heat after hiking Spur Cross Trail near Cave Creek.

A strong ridge of high pressure over the western CONUS resulted in excessive heat conditions across the Phoenix area for the end of August. Temperatures at Phoenix Sky Harbor topped out at 111 degrees on the 30th, while low temperatures near 90 degrees provided little overnight relief from the heat. Above normal temperatures continued into the start of September. According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 9 heat-associated fatalities occurred during this event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four direct fatalities were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures in the upper 90s to low 100s were experienced in the lower elevations of southeast Arizona on May 26-27. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for seven individuals. Four were found in the desert, two on the Tohono O'odham Nation, and two in Cochise County. The other three victims were elderly individuals in Tucson.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot temperatures 5 to 10 degrees above normal, around 100 degrees, were experienced on the Tohono O'odham Nation on May 26 causing the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for two individuals found in the desert, one north of San Miguel and another east of Sells.

CZ_NAME: UPPER SANTA CRUZ RIVER AND ALTAR VALLEYS
EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 7 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in the lower elevations of Pima, Santa Cruz, Graham, Greenlee and southeast Pinal counties June 9-12, with high temperatures equaling or exceeding established records in several locations. Hot temperatures 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced in Cochise County. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for a total of 11 individuals.  Six individuals found in the desert, two on the Tohono O'odham Nation, one in Santa Cruz County, two in southeast Pima County and one in Tucson Mountain Park. Four victims were found in the Tucson (2 indoors and 2 outdoors), and another individual perished in his home in Bowie.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures of 102 to 109 degrees occurred and caused the High Heat Risk category to be reached. Nogales airport set a record with 105 degrees on the 10th and Sasabe reached 109 degrees on the 11th and 12th. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found in the desert near Ruby on the 10th.

According to the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, 13 heat-associated fatalities occurred due to this heat event.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three fatalities (1 direct and 2 indirect) were reported by the Maricopa County Department of Public Health, with their details, such as age, gender, circumstances, and exact location unavailable.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Very hot temperatures 7 to 10 degrees above normal were experienced in the lower elevations of Pima, Santa Cruz, Graham, Greenlee and southeast Pinal counties June 9-12, with high temperatures equaling or exceeding established records in several locations. Hot temperatures 4 to 7 degrees above normal were experienced in Cochise County. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for a total of 11 individuals.  Six individuals found in the desert, two on the Tohono O'odham Nation, one in Santa Cruz County, two in southeast Pima County and one in Tucson Mountain Park. Four victims were found in the Tucson (2 indoors and 2 outdoors), and another individual perished in his home in Bowie.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hot high temperatures of 100 to 104 degrees occurred and caused the Moderate Heat Risk category to be reached. The Pima County Medical Examiner determined that heat was the primary cause of death for one individual found in his home in Bowie.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Very hot high temperatures of 104 to 109 degrees occurred with low temperatures in the upper 70s to lower 80s, and caused the High Heat Risk category to be reached. Tucson airport tied set records with 109 degrees on the 10th and 11th and Green Valley topped out at 107 degrees. The Pima County Medical Examiner confirmed that heat was the primary cause of death for seven individuals. On the 10th, two were found in the desert near Amado and two in Tucson (1 indoors and 1 outdoors). On the 11th, another was found outdoors in Tucson. On the 12th, one was found in Tucson Mountain Park west of Tucson and another indoors within the City of Tucson.

Strong high pressure over the region resulted in extreme temperatures. An Excessive Heat Warning conditions were met in the Phoenix area from the 4th through the 7th for temperatures reaching upwards of 105-110 degrees. In the Cave Creek area, a group of 6 hikers ran out of water and were overcome by the heat on the 5th. One of the hikers ended up passing away due to the heat.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In the early afternoon, 6 hikers 4 miles in on Spur Cross Trail became lost, ran out of water, and their phones died. After finally getting word out, first responders were able to rescue the hikers and airlift them to a hospital. One hiker did not survive. A Scottsdale Fire Captain said the individual died due to heat exhaustion and heat stroke. The Maricopa County Office of the Medical Examiner listed the primary cause of death as dehydration and heat exposure. Temperatures in the early afternoon were around 103-105 degrees.
